Very often it happens that there is a flow of blood from an artery which has been cut at a wound, which occurs externally, or at the incision of an abscess, or the cautery of a limb, and similar things to these; and it becomes difficult to stop it.  
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	Therefore when this happens to someone then hurry with your hand to the orifice of the artery and place your index finger upon it; and press it very much until the blood is confined beneath your finger and nothing comes out from it.  
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then place a small olive-wood cautery into the fire, and many more of a large size; and blow upon them until they become very ignited.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one from them, either a small or large one according to the wound and the place where the artery has been severed, and apply the cautery upon it; after which you quickly remove your finger and hold the cautery until the blood is cut off.  
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	If it is expelled when you raise your finger from the orifice of the artery and you extinguish the cautery, then quickly take another cautery from those that are prepared in the fire. 
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Therefore do not cease to do this with one after the other until the blood is cut off.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And beware that you do not burn the nerve which is there, and other harm befall the sick person. 
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery it is not possible to cut it off; especially when the artery is large, except with one of four methods. 
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we have said. 
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction, when it has not been extracted. 
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its extremities contract, and the blood is cut off. 
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is tied with a strong ligature thread. 
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or medicines of a nature to cut off blood are placed upon it, and it is bound with a decent constricting bandage. 
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	But whoever performs its cutting off with a ligature, and constriction with cloth, or application of burning things, and similar methods, does not heal it completely except rarely. 
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if it should happen to someone and there is no doctor or medicine present, then let him begin by placing the index finger over the opening of the vein itself, as we have described, and constricting it tightly until the blood is blocked from above the wound and over the artery. 
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be removed, but water of a very cold temperature should constantly be poured over it until the blood freezes and thickens, and is cut off. 
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	Meanwhile he should consider what he needs from a cautery or medicine.  
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of the First Part. 
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	The Second Part of the Surgical Book of Albucasis. 
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Incision, Perforation, and Phlebotomy in Wounds and Similar Things. 
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already said in the First Chapter that every illness for which it is appropriate to use fire with a cautery and burning medicine, its occasions, causes, instruments, and forms of cauteries. 
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed chapters there from the head to the foot. 
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter the same way so that it may be relieved for the one seeking his question. 
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, it is necessary that you learn, oh sons, that in this chapter there is from the terror that which is in the first chapter on cauterization.  
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And on account of that it is necessary that there be more caution in this one, because in the operation which is in this chapter, very often evacuation occurs with blood, with which life stands at the opening of a vein, or incision over an abscess, or opening of an exit wound, or healing of a wound, or extraction of an arrow, or incision over a stone, and those similar: from all of which trembling and fear are associated, and death falls upon many of them. 
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, lest that which is hesitation fall upon you, for sometimes there fall upon you in this art ways of men with ways of illnesses. 
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For from them is he who becomes angry with his illness, and death is easy for him on account of the vehemence which he finds from his illness and the length of its malice.  
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And with illness there is fear which signifies death. 
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And from them is he who gives his lyre player and enriches you with it, hoping for healing, and his illness is harmful. 
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore it is not necessary that you consent to him who comes to you from them, whose way is such. 
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be more vehement than your greed and your avarice.  
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume upon anything from that, except after certain knowledge, which verifies at you that to which praiseworthy succession arrives. 
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use in the healing of all your sick a prognosis and an indication concerning it to which conveniently belongs health.  
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in that there is help for you in acquiring fame and glory, and memory and praise. 
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire in you his intellect, and not take away from you direction and inspiration: for that is in his hand. 
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I indeed ordered this chapter by distinguishing it into chapters, according to what preceded in the chapter on Cautery, from the neck down to the feet: so that you may be relieved of what you seek and need from it.  
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Concerning the treatment of water which gathers in the heads of children. 
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this infirmity often happens to boys at birth: or when the midwife tightens the head of the boy without gentleness. 
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever it also happens from a hidden cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I indeed have not seen this illness in anyone but boys; and to all whom I have seen from them, death has hastened: therefore it seemed to me to abandon the operation in it. 
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I indeed saw from them a boy whose head was filled with water, and his head swelled every day until he could not sit upon himself because of the size of his head: and the humidity increased until he died. 
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this humidity indeed gathers either between the skin and the bone; or it gathers under the bone above the suture.  
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation in that case, if it is humidity between the skin and the bone, and it is a small abscess, then it is necessary for you to make a fissure in the middle of the head one fingerbreadth wide: and let the length of the fissure be as much as two knuckles until the humidity runs out. 
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the form of a spatula. 
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the humidity is increased more and the abscess is larger, then make those two fissures according to this form.  
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the humidity is under the bone and the sign of it is that you see the sutures of the head open from every side: and the water sinks when you press it with your hand to its inside, and it is not hidden from you; then it is necessary for you to make in the middle of the head three fissures according to this manner.  
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, extract all the moisture. 
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then bind the fissures with cloths and lint. 
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then embrocate it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day. 
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the bandage, and care for the wound with tents and ointments. 
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not allow the head to be compressed evenly.  
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the weak with all dry food of little humidity, until the limb is strengthened and healed. 
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another manner of incision is, that you consider where the magnitude of the abscess appears, and the collection of water. 
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes it is more at the back of the head, or at the top of the head, or on the right, or on the left. 
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore ascend with the incision where you see the abscess and the filling of water: and cleave it according as is possible for you. 
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, lest you strike an artery, and there be a flow of blood, and the weak person dies from that flow with the evacuation of moisture. 
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Concerning the incision of arteries which are behind the ears. 
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When it happens to someone that catarrh occurs at the eyes, or at the chest, and it becomes old, and treatment with medicines does not benefit it: then a more final remedy is in this case, incision of these two arteries. 
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore it is necessary when you wish to incise them, that the sick person shall shave his head.  
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the place with a rough cloth, so that the arteries may appear. 
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then let the sick person compress his neck, with any of his cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the vein pulses. 
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places of both are places which are depressed behind the ears: and it rarely conceals itself, unless in some people. 
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with a cautery over each one; and incise each one with a scalpel on both sides, the incision reaching the mouth; and let it be done across the width of the head. 
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert a speculum beneath the artery and cut it above with an incision. 
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be like two joined fingers. 
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when a vein is cut, blood flows out in a pulsing stream, which rises to the insides with frequent leaps. 
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not appear to the sense, then it is necessary that you measure from the ear a distance of three fingerbreadths. 
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with sealing wax and cut down to the bone.  
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which ought to be emitted from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps you may emit from it more or less. 
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All of this according to the quantity which appears to you from the weakness of the sick person and the fullness of his artery.  
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider the wound. 
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if anything remains at the bone from the incision, then cut it so that a hot abscess may not occur: then bind the wound with strips of linen cloth.  
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it is healed. 
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	Concerning the extraction of arteries which are in the temples. 
Caput III.	Chapter III. 
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man that he has an old headache or sharp catarrh because of acrimonious humors and heat in the temples, or an old soda, vehement, and similar things: and it is treated with the methods of medical treatment and it does not help, then we have found in these illnesses the extraction of arteries from the temples, or cauterization of them, as we have narrated.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in extracting them is that the sick person shaves the hairs which are in the temples and stretches towards the apparent artery in the temple. 
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For it indeed shows itself to you from its pulse and rarely is it concealed except in a few people or vehement cold. 
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is concealed from you, then let the weak person bind their head with any cloth they have: then rub the place with a rough cloth. 
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or vaporize the place with warm water until it appears to you manifestly. 
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the spatula, which I had previously made. 
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then flay the skin with it easily until you reach the artery. 
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then throw a hook into it and draw it upwards until you draw it out of the skin and make it come out from all the tunics that are under it. 
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	But if the artery is slender: then enfold it with the extremity of the hook. 
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut a part from it according to the amount by which its extremities are lengthened and contracted so that bleeding does not occur. 
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not incised and if it is not cut off, the blood does not ascend thoroughly.  
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then evacuate from the blood six ounces up to three. 
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if the artery is large: it is necessary that you tie it in two places with a strong double silk thread: or with al-hodad cords so that putrefaction does not hasten to it before the consolidation of the wound and bleeding occurs. 
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut off the excess which is between the two ligatures.  
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do that in that hour or another hour. 
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery up to the bone with a knife cautery until its extremities fall and it stands in place of the same work. 
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is a better operation unless the weak person has a fever or a hot complexion.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Because a cautery is one of those that help to finish humidities. 
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is a better remedy. 
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the extraction of the arteries, that the place be filled with well-cooked lint: and let poultices be placed on top of it loosely made.  
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the loosening, it should be treated with dry medicines, which cause flesh to grow, and with dressings, until it is healed. 
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	And if meanwhile while you are working there should occur a flow of blood from an artery, then hasten to cut it off with a cautery, or to fill the place with wool; and bind your hand until the blood is severed.  
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	And if none of these things are present to you, then place your finger upon the place until the blood coagulates. 
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And embrocate the place with water of violent cold, until the sharpness subsides, and it is bound as is necessary. 
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And because that which is lighter and easier for the extraction of an artery is, to cauterize the vein with this cautery having two knives; let the sharpness of the two knives be like a razor. 
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However they are of much less sharpness than two knives.  
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are sharp like two knives, cold quickly follows to both; and they do not strike the flesh with speed.  
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Therefore since there is a little thickness in them, the heat of the fire is retained in them, and the flesh is cut quickly; with this therefore the work is better than all other work, and lighter, and easier.  
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space which is between the two knives be the thickness of a finger, after you have marked two places with sealing wax; and lay both ignited strongly, until they reach the mouth, and they strike the vein in two places: so that what is between its ends is lengthened.  
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they are not fully consolidated with this cautery. 
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery.  
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	On the treatment of sharp, persistent courses of tears from the eyes. 
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are persistent and the course of them is from the veins which are upon the exterior skull; and no medicine treatment confers anything upon them with medicines, and you see the face of the sick person already reddening, and he feels in his forehead a walking motion, as there is a walking motion of ants; and his eyes are weakened, moist, so that his hairs are already corroded by corrosion; and his eyelids are heated from the sharpness of the tears; then the ancients used this operation in their treatment, and they called it treatment with a Sword. 
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is to be commanded that the patient shave the hairs on his forehead. 
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions in the forehead at equal distances according to the length of the forehead; and let the length of each incision be about two fingers; and let one incision be equidistant from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second a little distance beyond the length according to the movement of the tear ducts, and the third on the other side; and beware of cutting the arteries which are on both sides; and extend your hand from the continuation of the two mandibles, and let the space of the whole incision be the size of three joined fingers; and have a piece of sponge or many dry cloths ready with which to dry the blood. 
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce a speculum with two pointed ends, of which the following form will be.  
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision which is from the temple side to the second incision; and with it flay all the skin that is between the two incisions, along with the flesh which is above the mouth. 
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do the same from the middle incision to the second incision. 
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then withdraw this speculum and insert into the first incision again another instrument which is called a sharp curette, blunt on one side and not sharp on the other. 
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.  
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place the sharp side of it toward the flesh joined with the skin, and the blunt side towards the mouth; and press it until it reaches the middle fissure; and cut off with it all the vessels that descend from the head to the eyes, except that the incision be continued up to what appears from the skin. 
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do the same in the middle fissure up to the other fissure.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when an equal quantity runs out of blood, squeeze out the places from the clots of congealed blood. 
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place a linen wick steeped in old wine upon all the fissures; and put poultices soaked in wine, oil or vinegar over them. 
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see that a hot abscess does not occur. 
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day, loosen the ligature, and administer much infusion with warm water. 
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with royal ointment, and other things with which wounds are healed: until it is healed. 
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	On the treatment of sharp tears and cataracts to the eyes from within the head.
Caput V.	Chapter Five. 
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When acute, sharp, and persistent catarrs occur to someone: and you see his eyes weakened, small, and their aspect already debilitated: and the eyelids ulcerated, and hair falls out from them, and there is a sharp, hurting pain in the depth of the head, and consequent sneezing: then take from these accidents that those matters and catarrhs do not come except from many veins. 
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the better cure in them is this.  
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is, that you order the sick person to shave his forehead. 
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make one fissure in the middle of the forehead, or another a little further by width, and begin with the fissure from the left temple to the right temple: and let the incision be up to the mouth: and extend your hand from the muscles of the temples, which are moved at mastication: until when the mouth is uncovered: and you will dry all the blood with a sponge. 
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the fissure with old thread, or with linen strips. 
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then constrict from above with lint: and soak the lint with wine and oil, so that a hot abscess does not occur. 
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you loosen that, and you see that the hot abscess already diminishes: then it is necessary for you to cauterize the mouth until flesh begins to be born in it.  
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then treat it with a drying regimen that causes flesh to be born: such as if you take two parts from wheat flour, and four parts from colophony: and prepare an adhesive plaster from them, and administer it until the birth of flesh in these wounds.  
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	On the treatment of that which falls into the ear. 
Caput VI.	Chapter Six. 
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the ear is one of four types: either a mineral stone, or something like a stone, such as iron and glass; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is a fluid substance, such as water, vinegar, and things similar to them; or some animal. 
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	Therefore, when a stone or a type of stone falls into the ear from those which are not added to and do not grow in the ear, expose the ear to the sun: if then you see the stone, then distill something from violet oil or sesame oil into the ear.  
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then perform its extraction and make him sneeze with something that has been mashed up, and plug his nostrils at the time of the sneeze, after you place into the circumference of the ear wads from cloths or wool, and extend the ear upward. 
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Very often it comes out with this care.  
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not come out, then administer its extraction with forceps, that is, with subtle pincers: whose form is this. 
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If therefore it comes out with the forceps, it is good. 
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer its extraction with a thin blind hook of few turns.  
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If therefore it does not come out through that, then make a cannula from bronze, and insert the end of the cannula into the ear canal far, and plug what is in the circumference of the cannula with softened wax with oil so that there is no way for air except through the cannula: then extract it with your strong suction. 
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Very often it comes out with what we have narrated.  
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if it does not come out this way: then take a small amount from hellebore, or from birdlime, that is, prepared gluten with which birds are caught; and place it on the end of a probe after you have wrapped a well-placed wad upon it: then insert it into the ear canal with ease after you have dried the ear from moisture. 
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If therefore it does not go out with all that we have narrated, then hasten to incise, before a hot abscess or spasm occurs. 
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the manner of incision is, that the phlebotomist should first make a small incision on the cephalic vein; and draw from him blood according to his strength. 
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the sick person sit between your hands, and turn his ear upwards, and make a small incision at the root of the ear near his fat in a depressed place; and let the incision be crescent-shaped, until you reach the stone; then remove it with what is possible for you from the instruments. 
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then sew up the incision quickly with care, until it heals.  
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	But if the thing falling into the ear is one of the grains that grow and swell; then perform its extraction. 
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not yield to your efforts for removal, then take a fine, slender spatula according to this form.  
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And apply it to cut off that type of grain which falls into the ear, and do not do this when you think that the grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear until you have put many splinters into it; then extract them with hooks or a fine probe or suction as we have said, for its extraction is alleviated.  
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But as for the water which enters into the ear, it is necessary that the sick person should use sneezing when he first sits down; and he has already filled his ear with some old cooked oil; and he lies on that ear in which there is water. 
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it comes out through it, it is good. 
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones according to the length of a finger, thin and smooth, and heat them slightly with fire, and let the sick person insert one of them into the opening of his ear; and leap on one of his feet from that side, and strike it with another stone upon the one which is in the ear. 
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore, he should not cease to do that with stone and stone until all the water comes out. 
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now the water comes out so that you may take one from a crucible, or from a rush, and insert one of its ends into the ear; and you ignite the other end with fire until most of it is burned up. 
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat with another rush, and do that many times until all the water comes out; and extract it with a tube according to what was said in the stone. 
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	However, in the extraction of an animal entering into it, if it is of small body, such as a flea, and the like, take care of it as I said in the division. 
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of large body, which appears to the senses; then administer its extraction with gestures and hooks; and its matter is easier than all those that are held in the ear. 
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	However, in the extraction of a generated worm in the ear, when you care for it with what we said in the division and in the treatise on distillations, and your treatment does not work; then it is necessary that you look at the ear in the sun. 
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore something from worms appears there, then extract it with gestures or with subtle hooks.  
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing appears there, then take a tube, which has this shape, narrow below, wide above; and insert the subtle end into the ear according to the amount that the weak one can tolerate it; then suck with strong suction. 
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do that many times until all the worms come out.  
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they do not obey you for the exit, then cauterize the circumference of the tube with wax, as I said in the stone. 
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	But if they do not come out with what we said; then administer distillations which the ancients have already experienced in the infection of worms; and you will find it in the treatise on distillations. 
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your effusion with which you pour oil and medicines into the ear be with this instrument, whose form is depicted here. 
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, make it yourself from silver, or bronze, narrow below, in which there be a small hole, wide above. 
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let it therefore be so that driving what is in the concavity of the cannula, be made decently from bronze.  
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a ray, and involve cotton in its extremity with decent involution; then pour oil, or juice, or whatever you wish from these medicines into the cannula; and let the cannula itself be in the ear; then introduce the ray with cotton above, and press it with your hand with temperate compression until the oil is driven into the concavity of the hearing, and the sick person feels it within; and let that which is poured into the ear already be warmed a little with fire; and beware lest anything that is distilled into it be very cold: for medicines do not tolerate that. 
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the cure of an accidental Auricular Exudation. 
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes certain infants issue from the wombs of their mothers not perforated.  
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it also happens to some people that an exudation occurs in the auditory passage from a wound, or flesh born therein.  
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this exudation sometimes occurs in the depth of the ear hole, which does not follow sight; and sometimes it happens to the outer part of the hole a little, and follows it by sight. 
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which occurs in the depth of the ear, and which does not comprehend the view, is in many dispositions difficult healing. 
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which follows sight, it is necessary for you to place the ear of the sick person in the sun, and look into it; then if you see an apparent exudation, open it with a subtle speculum, whose form is as follows: let its extremity be where there is a small breadth, of which a part be acute; and let the rest of the speculum be of two smooth sides, so that it does not injure the ear. 
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If therefore the growth is from the flesh born in the ear canal: then hold it with a fine hook, and cut into it with strong ease, until all the flesh is removed. 
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	But if the growth is deep in the ear: then take a fine, gentle ray, and heat it slightly with fire: then put it into the ear canal. 
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If therefore you perceive the growth with that which the weak find with gravity of hearing, endeavor its opening with ease: and beware, lest you wound the nerves of the ear. 
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place in the ear a linen compress according to the quantity of the amplitude of the hole which you have wrapped in Egyptian ointment: do this for several days until you are sure of the healing of the wound. 
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take linen and infuse it in rose water, and sprinkle upon it powdered zedoary, and use it. 
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	But if you see the ear already to have become abscessed: then it is necessary that you remove the linen and allow it with another linen which you wrap in cerate made with rose oil, until the hot abscess subsides: then care for it until it heals.  
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	But if a flow of blood should occur: then immerse a sponge or cloths in cold water and place them upon the ear: and use the remaining care which separates the flow of blood as mentioned in the treatise on distillations.  
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Concerning the Care of Althel's Eyelids. 
Caput VIII.	Chapter Eight. 
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These althel which occur on the eyelids of the eye are sometimes moist, and sometimes dry. 
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore it is necessary that you hold them with tweezers: or with a hook, and cut into them with a scalpel from their roots. 
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place upon the spots powdered zedoary. 
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	But if blood should flow from them, then cauterize them with a fine lentil-shaped cautery.  
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And to cauterize them, is better after incision. 
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For very often they return when something remains from their roots. 
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and they do not return. 
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	On the Treatment of Hailstones on the Eyelid. 
Caput IX.	Chapter Nine.  
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Very often there occurs in the eyelids something which is likened to a Hailstone in its firmness and hardness, and on account of that it is called a Hailstone: and it is an aggregation of thick humidity in the upper eyelid, and the lower eyelid. 
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Therefore the operation on them is, that you consider then whether it is a Hailstone proceeding from it, which appears from the eyelid and moves to every part, and its matter is easy. 
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Therefore make above it a fissure through its breadth.  
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape it from every part with ease until it comes out. 
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a hook and cut it off.  
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if the cutting of it is not prepared for you except after you penetrate the eyelid with an incision a little, then that harms the weak one somewhat.  
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the fissure is large: then join it together with suture: and take care of it until it heals. 
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.  
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For ointment restores it and makes it flesh. 
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the hailstone is sloping toward the inner parts of the ear toward its inner surface, then turn back the eyelid and suspend the hailstone with a hook; besides which you will need an incision and press it from every part.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	But if the eyelid is lengthened by the incision, that does not harm anyone somewhat.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision of the hailstone with salt water and take care of the place with that which makes flesh until the weak one heals. 
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the Treatment of Eyelash Ailments. 
Caput X.	Chapter Ten. 
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a fat which is generated in the tunic of the upper eyelid; and it most often happens to boys; and it weighs down their eyes, and they have catarrhs in the mornings, and they cannot look at the light of the sun, because tears rush to them, and on account of that you see them lying face down upon themselves always, and sleeping on them, and their eyelids are moist beneath their eyebrows, which already has been covered by swelling; and indeed the eminence of Axirnath is visible to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.  
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of operating on it is for the patient to put his head in your lap. 
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare on it tow, and make from the tow a circle according to the quantity which contains the Axirnath on all sides.  
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place him upon it and press with your fingers from all sides so that the Axirnath gathers in the middle of the circle. 
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that moisture with an entering scalpel fissures across its width, and let there not be a fissure larger than that which is made in phlebotomy in depth. 
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or it is necessary that you cut all the skin until you reach the Axirnath; for in many dispositions the Axirnath proceeds from the fissure according to the shape of a white tallow candle.  
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Therefore extract it with the cloth which you inserted between your fingers to the outside; and you turn your hand to the right and left until it is dispersed; and beware lest you add anything in the fissure so that you do not reach with the scalpel to the eye and injure it. 
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if the Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the fissure, you add a little into the fissure with ease until the Axirnath proceeds.  
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it, as we have said. 
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse cloths in vinegar and water, and place them over the area, and bind it with bandages.  
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are those among men who grind salt, and put it into the hollow of the fissure so that it liquefies what remains from that moisture. 
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals. 
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if a hot abscess should occur there, then treat it with soothing plasters until it heals. 
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	On the methods of treating a relaxed eye, that is, when the eyelid softens, causing it to bulge as it should not. 
Caput XI.	Chapter XI. 
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When hairs in addition to the natural course of hairs are born on the eyelids, and grow crooked: then they harm the eye, and cause illnesses to occur, such as continuous tears, and softening of the eyelids, and leukoma, until it becomes a cause of the destruction of the eye.  
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And indeed, relaxed eye is treated according to four methods. 
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cautery with fire. 
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with a sharp medicine, as previously stated in the chapter on cautery.  
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or relaxed eye is treated by incision and suture. 
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by means of canes, as I will explain.  
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You must place the head of the sick person on your lap. 
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	Therefore if it is turned, it is good.  
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: insert a needle into it, in which there is a thread from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle with thread penetrate from above, so that it is near the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid where the hairs are born: then draw the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it with a rod. 
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find on the inner part of the eyelid under the added hairs with the spatula incident from the larger lacrimal to the smaller lacrimal. 
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then extract the thread, and place under the eyelid a small ball of lint from cotton or cloth; then mark upon the eyelid with cerate in the form of a myrtle leaf. 
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However it is necessary that the figure be made according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid; because this is now diversified in men. 
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For among them there are some who need a large quantity to be cut from the eyelid according to the quantity that is softened by the eyelid. 
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with the spatula find above the two lines that you have marked and begin from the larger lacrimal to the smaller lacrimal, and let there be one fissure near the natural hairs as is the thickness of a ray.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the hook into one of the two angles of the skin. 
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scarify the entire skin itself.  
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then join the two lips with suture using a sharp needle and fine wool thread; and wash away the blood, and make what overflows from the threads adhere to the two eyebrows with certain occult things if you wish to do this; and if not, do not care.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then leave the suture and threads for three or four days, then afterward take care of it. 
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without suture and care for it with that which dries and constricts it.  
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid rises at the sealing of the wound and its joining; but it will be better in the future. 
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of healing was taught by the ancients according to Ataxmir.  
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However there is anxiety about the sick person, and it is from a good operation, and there is no fear in it. 
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And there is another method in Ataxmir also; and it is that you mark upon the eyelid a figure which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf as we have narrated. 
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then raise the eyelid with three separate or joined hooks, according to this form, and then cut off what overflows with small forceps, according to this form, with equal incision. 
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if it is not possible for you to hold the hook, and it does not fit: then take a needle with thread in it, and insert it into the middle of the figure; and insert another thread near the larger lacrimal, and a second thread near the smaller lacrimal; and join the threads between your fingers equally.  
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand with equal elevation; and raise the skin above which is the marked cot, as we have described.  
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join the two lips of the wound with suture; and care for it until it heals. 
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if an abscess should occur at your incision or fissure: dry it up with cerate and the like, from soothing ointments. 
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens that the eyelashes of the eyelid also turn around. 
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore, you must use what we said in the incision; but the suture for both is more artful.  
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	Concerning the care of Ataxmir with dogs. 
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	AND it is necessary to turn the eyelid and split the fissure that is within, according as I have described.  
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two canes, or two slender pieces of wood; whose length is according to the length of the eyelid, and whose width is less than the width of a span; and you have already cut into the ends of each from both sides where you hold the threads.  
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then join each with subtlety over what overflows from the eyelid of the eye, and tighten the two canes from both sides with a strong binding, and leave it for several days. 
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin that is tightened will die and blacken and putrefy until it falls off by itself. 
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If then it is delayed, cut it with forceps. 
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals. 
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore it becomes firm, elevate the eyelid: and the hairs do not sting. 
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of two tubes, which you will make according to this figure, and quantity in length and width. 
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	On raising stinging hairs in the eye with a needle. 
Caput XII.	Chapter Twelve.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation on it is, that you take a fine needle, and insert into it a fine, soft thread from silk.  
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then you gather its extremities, and tie both with a fine knot very tightly: and let the length of the threads be one palm. 
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then place another fine thread under it briefly in an Alinxotati, and tie its extremities if you wish. 
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then let the patient put his head in your lap, and be near the sun so that the operation is declared: because it is a subtle, or minute operation. 
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with the Alinxotati into the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate into the eyelid quickly, until you draw it out from above the natural hair.  
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw the hair up to above the Alinxotati: and insert into the Alinxotati that hair: if it is one, or two, or three, no more. 
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw your hand with it until the hair emerges with the Alinxotati into the eyelid with the natural hair. 
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	But if the Alinxotati is drawn, and the hair does not emerge with it: draw the Alinxotati downwards, with the thread which you placed in it, until the Alinxotati emerges from the upper opening, and you see it with the eye's vision: then indeed draw the Alinxotati and the thread: and pull out both, and close the eye: and let it remain closed for two days, or three, until the hair adheres to its place, and flesh grows over it.  
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either join to it a long hair from natural hairs, and raise it with it; or leave it alone until it lengthens after a while, and then raise it. 
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	Concerning the care of alxatrati which occurs in the upper eyelid. 
Caput XIII.	Chapter Thirteen. 
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this alxatrati happens to the eye, it is called Leporina.  
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this alxatrati is either natural or accidental. 
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Accidental therefore arises from the consolidation of a wound, or incision, or cautery, and similar things to these.  
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of operation in this is that you open that consolidation and separate its lips, and put into it a ligature of linen thread, and bind it until it heals.  
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not necessary that you use things in its treatment which dry and constrict: for if you do that, the alxatrati returns worse than it was; rather use in it things which soften, such as fenugreek; and embrocate with water in which marshmallow root and flaxseed have been boiled; and ointment of dyaquilon which has been liquefied with some oil; and wrap it with a linen cloth, and care for it with that. 
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And the treasure of your treatment is, that you try with all your ingenuity, so that it does not consolidate according to the form which it was at first. 
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And indeed this operation which we have said is not except a certain correction of the alxatrati, so that it does not return to the form of the place according to what it entirely was. 
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Concerning the care of alxatrati which occurs in the lower eyelid, and is a wrinkle or contraction upward to the right and left. 
Caput XIIII.	Chapter Fourteen.  
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This alxatrati which occurs below is the one that truly is called alxatrati. 
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	It is natural and it is accidental. 
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental kind is made from a wound, or fissure, or cautery, and things similar to those. 
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way of operation on it is that you take a needle with a double thread and stain it with flesh color, and make it penetrate from the left tear duct to the right tear duct, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh. 
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh upwards with the needle and cut it with a broad scalpel. 
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	Therefore if the shape of the eyelid returns as it should be, it is good.  
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take a ray and place it in the fissure and turn it with the eyelid; and make two fissures on the inner side of the eyelid, let the ends of the two fissures be from the two angles of the incision until they meet and form an angle: until when they come together the shape of them becomes this shape, and it is the letter lambda.  
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by the amount which is its sharp lower side, from that which follows the eyelid. 
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join the separate parts; sew them with wool thread.  
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we said, about softening medicines and cleansing ones, until they are healed. 
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if a luxation should happen from the fissure and suture or cautery: then it is necessary that you make a flat fissure under the eyelashes of the eyelid, also according to what preceded.  
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with cleanser, according to what we said. 
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the sum of the speech about the care of luxation, when it is above or below, is that the operation runs in it according to what is prepared from the form of the luxation. 
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For it itself is of many different forms; and a skillful craftsman prepares his ingenuity with whichever way is possible for him, until he may return the shape to its natural form or near it, and himself, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in many positions.  
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Concerning the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva, or cornea. 
Caput XV.	Chapter Fifteen. 
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this consolidation occurs in many people, so that the upper eyelid consolidates with the white of the eye and prevents it from its natural operations. 
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore, you must insert the extremity of a radius under the eyelid and raise it upward; or extend it with a hook; then incise the adhesion with a fine spatula, which is not sharp like the incision of other spatulas, but rather slightly blunt: so that the weak person is not disturbed during the operation, and the spatula is removed and does not injure the eye with its sharpness; and let your incision be as if you were scraping away that adhesion easily, until the eyelid returns to its natural form, and the entire adhesion is healed. 
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salt water into the eye, with blue water itself; or distill into it from a sieve made, from ziniar dissolved with water. 
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with flaxseed linen; and place wool infused with egg white on the eye; and after the third day use a sieve, and with compresses, until it is healed. 
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	Concerning the incision of the nail and eminence of the lacrimal flesh.
Caput XVI.	Chapter Sixteen. 
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the nail is according to two ways.  
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Either it is nervous; and it is similar to a hard, thin reed. 
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to frozen white humidity; which when it touches iron, or you try to grasp it with a hook, it breaks off, and the hook does not stick in it.  
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds do not begin except from the larger lacrimal, until it gradually spreads, until it covers vision and prevents light and the movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of operating in its incision is: that the weak person should place their head in your lap.
