Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes and raise his eyelid with your hand. 
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then take a nail with a small hook and extend it upward. 
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle and insert into it a hair from the hairs of a horse, ox, or cow; and let the thread be strong, and double the end of the needle a little, and fix it in the middle of the nail; and penetrate it with the needle, and tie the nail with the thread, and extend it upward: and flay with the hair the side of the nail which follows the pupil, as if you were to grasp it with the hair up to its end. 
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remainder at the root of the lacrimal with a fine speculum, or with small forceps; and let go the natural flesh of the lacrimal, so that a constant course of tears does not occur from its incision.  
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the nail is extended with the hook alone; or with thread, as we have said. 
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then flay it with a gentle speculum, which has this shape.  
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And be careful that the speculum does not touch the corneal tunic, and a rupture occurs in it, and the pupil is perforated. 
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the incision, throw something crushed salt, or made from a sieve out of ziniar into the eye and leave it until the next day.  
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of it with what is necessary until it is healed. 
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	But if the nail is not nervous and you cannot insert a needle into it, nor does a hook attach to it, then this kind of nail is often healed with medicine, and is healed as I have related in the division. 
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	But if you wish to cut it, then open the eye of the sick person and take a subtle, gentle, dull-pointed speculum, according to this form.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And shave the nail from above with reason and subtlety. 
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it becomes thin and breaks up, and a razor presses into it, then distill from your hour into the eye a sieve made of zinc, or a red sieve, or ground salt; and bathe the eye until another day. 
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat the operation on it until all of it is removed. 
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless there is a hot abscess in your eye; for then let it alone and treat the abscess until it heals. 
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation on it with a razor until it heals. 
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	But if the prominence of the tear duct causes great harm to the eye, suspend it with a hook and cut a part from it; and do not close the incision so that the course of tears does not occur.  
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then instill into the tear duct a red sieve or one made from zinc until it heals. 
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	On the incision of Alguardenic and flesh born in the eye. 
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.  
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	Sometimes red flesh is born in the eyes of some men, superimposed or composed, until it covers the pupil, or approaches it, or tightens upon the eyelids, and perhaps turns the eyelids outward; and it resembles a rose balustrade. 
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And there is also an operation on it, so that the sick person places his head on your lap. 
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open his eyes and collect all that flesh with suitable hooks; and hold it with one forceps or a hand. 
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh first until all of it is finished with a surgical knife.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And be careful of the eye so that you do not injure it during the operation; and let your incision with which you cut it, be either with a scalpel, which we have described in the incision of a nail, or with small forceps, with which pus is collected, according to what its form will come after this chapter.  
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When therefore your incision is complete, and the whole of the algardenici is removed, then fill the eye with pounded salt: or distill into it red powder, and those similar to it from corrosive medicines: and put on the eye outside cotton with linen so that it may be guarded against a hot abscess. 
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	But if anything remains of the algardenici, and hot blood dominates you, and you fear a hot abscess: then leave the eye alone, and treat it with that which subdues an abscess.  
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the procedure upon it until it is healed. 
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And do similarly with added flesh which occurs in the eye from this kind.  
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	However it is necessary that strangers should perform the treatment of every weak eye from natural or accidental causes with iron; and do not put your hand into any of these operations until you see that that member can tolerate it. 
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	On the Collection of Sebum from the Eye.  
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Sebum are red veins which spread over the eye and prevent vision from its operation: and they weaken the eye with the length of days.  
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	It is necessary therefore for you first to consider if the eye in which there is sebum is strong and there is no sickness in it except the sebum: then collect its sebum. 
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is necessary that you instruct the weak person to put their head in your lap.  
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those veins with one hook, or two according to your prudence: and let the hook be subtle of double shape, according to this form, or let there be two hooks graded into one body, according to this form. 
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then collect those veins with subtle forceps with subtlety, and wash away the blood hour by hour until you see those veins being removed from the eye and resolved; and be careful not to injure the eye with the ends of the speculum.  
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	Let your operation be in the middle of the day before the sun, and be very steadfast in your operation so that you do not fall except upon those veins. 
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then distill into the eye a green or red sieve so that its sharpness may corrode what remains from the sebum. 
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	But if it is not possible for you to collect all of it in that hour, then plaster the eye with something which quiets the pain of the eye and let it be for several days until its pain subsides and guard it from a hot poultice; then repeat upon it in the same manner until it is healed. 
Et haec est forma forficis.	And this is the form of the forceps. 
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	Concerning the reduction of a deviated septum to the nose.  
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX. 
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	Physicians call a deviated septum a fistula, which you should treat with a cautery or with a sharply burning medicine, according to what was previously stated concerning it. 
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it does not heal, then there is no skill in it except to cut above the abscess at its origin and extract all the moisture that is in it and the pus until the opening is exposed. 
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	Therefore, when the opening is exposed and you see corruption or blackness in it, then excise it with an instrument whose form is this. 
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called an Asperi's head. 
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Let it be made of tempered iron, and let its head be round like an azir, which should be punctured with the puncture of a file or with a delicate puncture of a sharp chisel and place it upon the corrupted place of the bone. 
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then revolve it between your fingers and press your hand upon it a little while until you know that the corruption has already been scraped away; and do this several times. 
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with drying astringent medicines.  
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	Therefore, if the place consolidates and flesh grows in it and the flow of blood is cut off; and it remains for forty days and does not reoccur and does not become abscessed and no accident happens to it: then you know that it has already been healed. 
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then there is no skill in it except to reduce the fistula to the nostril orifice, according to this manner. 
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is, so that you expose the second bone with an iron, or with a sharp medicine; and when the bone has been exposed, then take an auger according to this manner, let its iron end be triangular: and let its wood be a pyramid tapered down to the extremity, as you see. 
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place that upon the bone itself; and let it be near the tear duct; and extend your hand a little from the eye. 
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then revolve your hand with the auger until it penetrates the bone, and it feels weak; through this it finds wind coming out of it, when he holds his hand over his nose. 
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then restore the place with styptic drying medicines, as I taught you. 
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When therefore flesh is born, and the place hardens; then the matter which was flowing to the outside, returns to the nose; it is therefore lighter upon the weak spot.  
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	On the Reduction of an Eye Prominence. 
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When an eye protrudes with its entirety, and there is no vision impairment, nor diminution; then it is necessary that you loosen the weak spot: then phlebotomize him: afterwards apply cupping glasses to the neck without scarification, but with suction. 
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then place upon the eye a liniment which is made from acacia, and aloe, and frankincense, and sarcocolla.  
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind the eye from above upon a plaster with many powders. 
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the manner of powders is: that you take soft cloths, many, and double every cloth from them over four; make many from them; then place them one upon another, according to the amount which the eye needs: then bind upon them with a hard cloth, a strong binding. 
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And repeat aspirations with a syringe without scarification. 
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the aspirated fluid, and let the eye be kept closed day and night. 
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	But if the ligament again becomes softened, then it must be tightened much; then remove the ligature after a day and night, as we have said. 
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	Therefore, if you see the eye has already returned to its former tunic, it is good; and if not, then repeat the plaster, and the poultices, and the ligature, and the aspirations until it is healed. 
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	On the Incision of the Vitreous Tunic. 
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.  
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When a rupture occurs in the vitreous tunic, then it protrudes and proceeds outside the eyelids like a seed of the vitreous, and spoils the appearance of man because of it, and there is a desire to excise it: then the operation on it is as follows, according to what I relate: and it is, that you introduce a needle into the root of the vitreous from the lower to the upper part. 
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then introduce another needle in which there is a double thread from the lacrimal part, and make it penetrate; and let the first needle go according to its own position. 
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the place of the double thread, and tie with it the part of the vitreous around the needle; and tighten it very much. 
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then withdraw the needle, and place wool steeped in albumen over the eye; and let him be, until the thread falls with the vitreous. 
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat the eye with what strengthens it, until the wound is healed. 
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And sometimes the vitreous is constricted from every side with a circle made of cloth, until the eye adds great prominence.  
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then perforate it with a fine trocar that reaches the depth of the eye, and let the albuminous moisture flow, and let the eye descend, and enter immediately; then tighten it until it is healed. 
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	On the treatment of al-qonmāti. 
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII. 
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This ailment which is called al-qonmāti is nothing but a humor that collects in the eye, resembling descending water, and is not itself.  
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the method of operating on it is to have the patient sit upon a prepared seat, or straight. 
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take his head with your hands on both sides and move it until you see the humor come down towards your eyes. 
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then fix it so that it does not descend, and clear the vision; and let the patient see things as he used to see; and if it does not descend below, you know that it is water.  
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	But if the descent of the humor is not prepared as we said, then make the patient sit between your hands. 
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a fine spatula and with it make an incision above the corneal membrane a little at the continuation of the conjunctiva with the cornea in the crown until the humor emerges.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When it therefore emerges, then distill into the eye warm water in which you have mixed honey; or water in which you have already boiled fenugreek and honey; then treat it with the remaining treatment until it is healed.  
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	On the treatment of water that descends into the eye, or cataract. 
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII. 
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have already spoken of the kinds of water in the division, and what is suitable for piercing speech explaining and setting forth; then take that same thing according to health.  
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then it is necessary for you to make the patient sit between your hands squarely, opposite the light near the sun; and bind his sound eye, and bind it tightly; then hold down the eyelid of his eye with your right hand if the eye in which there is water is the left eye; or with your left hand if the eye is the right. 
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take with your right hand an al-ma'ghazal if the eye is the left; or with your left hand if the eye is the right. 
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the end of the almaga near the cornea for the width of a radius in the white of the eye apparent below the lesser lachrymal; then press the almaga with force and turn your hand with it until it enters into the albuginea of the eye; and you will feel that the almaga has now reached the empty space. 
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary that the measure of the journey of the almaga to its depth be the measure of the space which is from the pupil to the end of the blackness; and this is the cornea of the eye. 
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	For you will see it in the pupil itself by the vision of the eye, on account of the clarity of the tunic of the cornea.  
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the almaga up to the place where there is water. 
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press it down below with juice one after another. 
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	And if therefore the water descends immediately, then the sick man sees that upon which he opens his sight immediately, and the almaga in his eye. 
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest a little while. 
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	And if therefore the water descends, then place it second beyond that by which the almaga comes out. 
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When therefore it is fixed and does not ascend; then draw out the almaga with ease; and you turn your hand little by little. 
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve something of clear salt of gems in water; and wash the eye within it. 
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place outside the whole eye a plug, or wool steeped in rose oil, and albuginea; and bind it with the sound eye. 
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	We however, and those who are of our time, place upon it pounded cuminum with albuginea. 
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	But if the almaga does not obey you to enter into the eye on account of its hardness because it is from men whose eyes are very hard; then it is necessary for you to take a speculum, which is called an Alberid, whose form is this: 
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Therefore perforate it only with this conjunctiva and not your whole hand into the hole; and there is nothing else to do except make a way to the almond-shaped place underneath. 
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the almond as we have said. 
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And at the completion of your work, prepare for the sick man a well-made bedchamber in which he may sleep upon his back in a darkened room; and prohibit him from all motions and coughing; and give him food that soothes his nature; and let him not move his head to the right or left at all. 
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the ligature be according to its arrangement until the third day. 
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then loosen it in that darkened room and test his sight; and have him see things.  
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then return the ligature until the seventh day. 
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it is not fitting that he do this at the hour of healing or immediately after the incision; but rather, that others do it; because water ascends quickly through a forceful opening. 
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	But if a hot swelling occurs; then it is fitting that you loosen the eye before the seventh day and correct it with that which stills the swelling until it is stilled; then release his sight, and place upon his face a covering by which his vision may be regulated under those days, with him being in that darkened room. 
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then let him go out from the house gradually and frequent his own affairs.  
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know that in surgery the student is not excused from sight often; then let him dare upon the operation. 
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And now indeed there has come to us a certain one of those who are from Al-Arayrakh, who said that a device was made in Al-Arayrakh which is perforated so that it sucks up water. 
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	But truly I have not seen anyone in your land who has made this; nor have I read of it in any ancient book; and it is possible that it is new. 
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	These are the forms of species from the ulcer, so that it may stand over him who does not know them. 
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be made of bronze properly: and let their extremities be with this same subtlety triangular, and the extremity acute. 
Formae magda.	Forms of ulcers. 
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	Concerning the treatment of flesh born on the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIV.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	Sometimes diverse added fleshes are born in the nose, from which there is something that resembles a scorpion of many feet; and from it is cancerous flesh, stony, of a dark color; and from it is that which is soft flesh, not of a dark color. 
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	Therefore, in that which is soft flesh from these fleshes, not fraudulent nor cancerous, it is necessary for you to make the weak one sit between your hands opposite the sun, and open his nostrils, and throw a hook into those fleshes; then draw them outwards, and cut what you have grasped from them with a thin sharp scalpel on one side, until you know that all the flesh has now been removed. 
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	And if anything remained from that which its excision is not possible: then shave it with one of the subtle instruments with ease, until nothing remains from it. 
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	But if blood dominates you, or a hot abscess occurs: then oppose it by what is necessary: or if it is from malignant abscesses, then hurry to cauterize it until the blood is cut off and all flesh is removed. 
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then vinegar and water, or wine, should be thrown into the nose after the incision. 
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	But if the nose opens, and moisture proceeds from it up to the palate, then you know that it is now healthy.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	But if the moisture does not penetrate as it should, then you know that there is flesh born within it on the upper bones of the nose, to which the instrument did not reach with the incision. 
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Therefore, it is necessary for you to insert a linen thread which has some thickness, and make many knots in it; and place the distance of a finger, or less, between each knot: and have the weak one guide one end of the thread into his nose with a rod, or with whatever is possible for him after he has made it like a plowshare; and pull on his own odor until it reaches the back, and comes out over his throat. 
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And very often they do something like this dissection of a boy in schools; and it is an easy thing for whoever wants to do it. 
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place the two ends of the thread, one end that goes over the nose, and the other that remains in the nose. 
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then apply a carneal lock with the knots that are in the thread. 
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is already joined with the knots of the thread. 
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then pull out the thread and put in the nose after washing away the blood a linen cloth soaked in Egyptian ointment; do this for three days, or more, until the ointment eats away all that remains from the flesh.  
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then finally put a lead tube into the nose for several days until it heals. 
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	But if it needs treatment that will dry it up, use that.  
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	To make a nasal inhaler, with which oils and other medicines are distilled into the nose, make it from silver or bronze: it should be like a small lamp, open like a shell; and its passageway similarly. 
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish, make a closed tube, like a reed. 
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the shell of the instrument for making a nasal inhaler should be full and open; it should have a handle at its end with which you hold it when heating oil or whatever you wish from juices and flowing things in it. 
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the form of the instrument. 
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	On the care of a broken nose. 
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.  
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Very often a swelling arises at the end of the nose and it magnifies and increases with days until its appearance becomes ugly.  
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And because of that it is necessary to cut into it at the beginning of its appearance and eradicate all of it. 
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place on top of the spot either a cautery or a burning medicine that takes its place.  
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	Therefore, if the incision of this is delayed until it grows larger, then consider, if it is stony, hard, dark in color, and insensitive: then do not touch it with iron; for it is a cancerous ulcer. 
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	For I have often seen those who suffered a felon and great misfortune came upon him who had it.  
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the felon is soft to the touch, not dark in color, and you see that incision is possible throughout its entirety, then evacuate the weak spot, and cut it without fear, without hesitation: and care for the place with that which dries and constricts, until it heals. 
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	On the suture of the nose, lip, and ear. 
Caput XXVI.	Chapter Twenty-Six. 
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	Know that when a disruption of continuity occurs in one of these cartilages, little benefit results from surgery except in certain individuals.  
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when it happens to someone that they suffer one of these things, you must consider if it is a fresh wound with its own blood; and then join the two lips of the wound together with suture: then care for it until it heals.  
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the lips of the disruption have already been separated and each part has become healthy; then it is necessary that you scrape away all the skin from its surface until it bleeds. 
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then join the two lips together with suture and tighten them, and sprinkle dragon's blood and ground frankincense over it; and place a piece of diachylon plaster and some other consolidating plaster on top of the powders, and leave it bound for two or three days.  
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then unbind it and change the medicine; and leave it until the threads separate on their own. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.  
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of suturing is to join the disruption together either with needles as we have described in suturing the abdomen or to join the disruption with thread as I have taught you. 
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	On the Extraction of Nodes from the Lips. 
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII. 
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people indeed have hard swellings within their lips, similar to grains of herb, some smaller and some larger. 
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore, you must turn back the lip and cut over each node, suspending it with a hook and cutting into it from all sides. 
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the place after the incision with powdered tragacanth until the bleeding stops. 
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then wash it with vinegar and treat the area with it because of its astringent properties, until the wounds are healed. 
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	On the Incision of Flesh Born Over the Gum. 
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII. 
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Very often flesh grows over the gum, which the ancients call an abuluss.  
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	Therefore, you must either suspend it with a hook or hold it with forceps and cut it at its root, allowing the pus to flow or the blood.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then place powdered tragacanth or other astringent, drying powders over the area. 
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	But if the flesh returns after treatment, which often happens, then cut it a second time and cauterize it; for it will not return after cautery. 
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	On the Scraping of Teeth with Iron.  
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX. 
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	Sometimes rough and foul crusts accumulate on the surfaces of teeth, both inside and outside, and between the gums, often becoming blackened, yellowish, and even greenish, until corruption from them spreads to the gums, making the teeth foul. 
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	Therefore you must make the weak person sit between your hands and place their head in your lap, then with a file and rasp remove any crusts from the teeth where they appear to you like sand until nothing remains. Do the same for blackness, greenness, yellowness, and other discolorations until they are cleansed.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	Therefore, if that which is in them from the beginning of reasoning is taken away, it is good; and if not, then iterate reason over them on another day, the second, and the third, until finally study reaches what you wish. 
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And know that a tooth needs razors of various shapes, many figures; according to how your operation is prepared; for which the razor with which the tooth is shaved from the lower part is different from the razor with which it is shaved between the teeth, according to other forms. 
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And let these forms of razors be prepared by you, which you see. 
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	On the Extraction of Painful Teeth. 
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX. 
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	You ought to cure the tooth from its pain with all your ingenuity, and delay in its eradication.  
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For there is nothing which can supply its place when it is eradicated, because it is a lofty substance: until when there is no excuse for its eradication, then it ought to be eradicated when the infirm one is forced, so that it may be strengthened and certified by you as a painful tooth.  
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	Very often pain deceives the infirm, and they think that it is in the tooth which is sound and eradicate it; then the pain does not recede until the infirm tooth is eradicated.  
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	We have already seen this from the operation of phlebotomists. 
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	Therefore, when the painful tooth itself is certified by you, it ought to be scarified around with a spatulum, in which there is some virtue, until the gum is loosened from every part: then move it yourself with your fingers or with subtle forceps at first gradually, until you shake it. 
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place large forceps there with a good placement and the head of the infirm one between your knees which you have already held well so that it does not move: then draw the tooth according to straightness so as not to break it. 
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if it does not come out, then take some of those instruments and insert it under it from every part with ease, and try its movement as you did at first. 
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If, however, a tooth is perforated or corroded, then it is necessary that you fill the hole with cloth and tie it with the end of a fine wire so that it does not break during the time you constrict it with forceps. 
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And you must act very carefully with the scarring all around the gum on every side. 
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And guard your strength so that you do not break it, and a part of it remains, and it returns upon the weak one from that evil which is greater than his first pain. 
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And beware lest you do what ignorant phlebotomists do in their haste and boldness in its eradication, beyond what we have described to be administered. 
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	Very often they cause great infirmities to befall men, which are more difficult to break, and all its roots or some of them remain, or that they extract it with some bones of the mandible: as we have testified many times. 
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then wash after its eradication with wine, or with vinegar and salt. 
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If it should happen that blood flows from the places (for this often happens), then apply something from zegi and fill the place with it: and if not, cauterize it if zegi does not offer itself to you.  
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The shapes of the subtle forceps with which a tooth is moved first should have long shafts, a short handle, and be thick so that they do not bend when pressed upon a tooth: they should be like you see with large handles, until when you squeeze them they do not give way or bend; short shafts, and made of good iron or steel properly forged, straight-edged shafts: and on their extremities there should be teeth, some of which enter into others, and tighten with decent, strong constriction.  
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And sometimes the extremities are made like the shape of the mouth of a bird which is called a stork and they are strong constrictions. 
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	On the removal of teeth, and the extraction of broken jaw bones. 
Caput XXXI.	Chapter Thirty-One. 
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When there remains something broken during the removal of a tooth, it is necessary to place a compress with butter on the spot for one or two days until the area softens; then introduce an elevator or forceps into it, whose ends are similar to the beak of a bird called a stork. 
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	This is the shape of these forceps.  
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Let their extremities be made like a file inside: or like an awl. 
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not obey you in order to exit with these forceps, then it is necessary that you carve above the root and detach all the flesh, and insert an instrument called a small lever, whose shape is this. 
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Let its extremity be short and slightly thick, and let it not be soaked so that it does not break.  
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	Therefore, if the root comes out through that, it is good; and if not, you must pry with these other instruments whose shapes are these.  
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The shape of the first has a triangular extremity, in which there is a certain thickness. 
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The shape of the second has a slender triangular extremity. 
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	You can also pry with this instrument having two branches, whose shape is this. 
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with the other instruments and tools that preceded for the reason of teeth.  
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	You can also pry with this instrument which resembles a large hook of this shape, with a twisted triangular extremity, in which there is a certain thickness so that it does not break; and let it not be soaked.  
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that dental instruments are many; and similarly, the remaining instruments are not counted, and a skillful craftsman, subtle in his art, invents an instrument for himself according to what the operation and illnesses themselves indicate to him. 
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Because there are illnesses from which the ancients did not say an instrument, due to the diversity of their kinds.  
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, the jawbone or other bones of the mouth are broken, or become putrid: then carefully examine it in its place with the instruments and forceps which I have mentioned for the extraction of roots, and aid it with a speculum, the form of which is as follows. 
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Let there be something of a moderate size in it, so that the mouth may be drawn tight or held with it, and does not escape and wander, until the bone comes out; and restore the place with suitable medicines for that purpose. 
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there is a little putrefaction in the bone, then scrape it clean of its putrefaction and care for it until it heals. 
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	Of the Locking of Teeth Which Project Beyond Others. 
Caput XXXII.	Chapter XXXII. 
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth protrude not according to their natural course, it makes the form ugly; and especially when this happens in women and girls, namely those who are marriageable. 
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore it is necessary that you consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if a tooth is born after another tooth and does not fit, or its locking is not possible, nor its filing: then extract it; and if it is attached to another tooth, then cut it with this instrument, the form of which is as follows.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is like a small beak, and is made of hardened iron, with a very sharp end. 
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And let your incision be made upon it over many days, and because of the hardness of the tooth, and that another tooth may not be disturbed. 
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	But if it projects exposed to filing: then file it with a file of hardened iron, the form of which is as follows.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	Let it be entirely of iron, and its handle have very small points, just like the file with which needles are made; with which the tooth may be filed gradually over many days easily so that the tooth is not disturbed and falls out; then soften it at the end and extract it with certain rasps.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If it is dense, from which a part breaks off and injures the tongue, then it must be filed even until the roughness of that fracture is removed and it is made equal; and smoothed, so that it does not injure the tongue nor corrupt speech. 
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	On the Retention of Teeth with Gold Wires. 
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter Thirty-Three. 
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When the front teeth suffer a concussion and contusion from a blow or fall, and the infirm person cannot hold anything they eat on it lest it fall out: and you have treated them with astringent medications, but the treatment has not been successful; then there is an ingenious way to bind them with gold wire: for silver turns green and decays after a few days, but gold never changes. 
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the wire be medium in fineness and thickness according to the amount that fits between the teeth. 
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the method of retention is as follows: you take the wire and insert a double length of it between two sound teeth; then you weave the two ends of the wire between the loose teeth, whether there is one or more, until you reach with the weaving up to a sound tooth on the other side. 
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the weaving back to the side where you started; and tighten your hand with subtlety and wisdom until it is not moved at all; and let your constriction where you bind the wire be at the roots of the teeth so that it does not come loose. 
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut off the excess ends of the wire with forceps; and join both ends together and twist them with a gesture; and conceal them between a sound tooth and a loose tooth so that they do not injure the tongue; then let it remain tightened in this way. 
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	But if it loosens or breaks, bind them again with another wire and it will remain thus for the whole time. 
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the shape of the teeth and the figure of the retention of two sound teeth and two loose teeth, as you see. 
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes it happens that one or two teeth return to their places after a fall and are retained as we have described and remain; and this is not done except by a skillful, prudent, and experienced craftsman. 
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And sometimes one of the vaccine bones is adapted and made into the shape of a tooth, and it is placed in its place, from which the tooth is fortified and tightened as we said, and it remains and serves for a long time. 
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	On the Incision of a Ligament Which Occurs Under the Tongue and Prevents Speech.  
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Sometimes this ligament which occurs under the tongue is either natural, with which a man is born, or accidental, from a wound that has already healed. 
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation on it is to open the mouth of the sick person in your lap and lift up his tongue; then cut that nervous ligament across its width until the tongue is freed from its restraint. 
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is something of hardness and nodulation in it, and if it is from the healing of a wound, then project a hook into it and pierce it across its width until you strike the ligament and loosen the nodulation. 
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And be careful that there is no fissure deep in the flesh, and that you do not cut into an artery there, lest blood flow occur. 
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then wash the area of the incision with rose water or vinegar, or cold water.  
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place a linen ligature under the tongue, which the sick person should hold in his mouth every night so that it does not heal back together again. 
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	But if bleeding occurs, then put powdered alum on the area.  
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if blood overcomes you, then cauterize the area with a lenticular cautery which is suitable for it; then care for it as with the rest of the treatment until it heals. 
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	On the Extraction of a Ranula Which Occurs Under the Tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter Thirty-Five 
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	Sometimes an abscess occurs under the tongue resembling a small frog, preventing the tongue from its natural function; and perhaps it grows so large that it fills the mouth. 
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	The operation on it is to open the sick person's mouth in front of the sun and consider the abscess. 
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	Therefore, if you see it to be of a dark or black color, hard, and one to which the sick person does not feel sensation: then do not touch it, for it is cancer. 
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	But if it inclines toward whiteness, and there is moisture in it, then thrust a hook into it, and cut it with a fine scalpel, and free it from every part. 
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	And if blood overcomes you during your operation, then place ground zedoary upon it until the bleeding stops; then return to your operation until you extract it with all its contents.  
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then gargle it with vinegar and salt; and care for it with the remaining treatment suitable for it until it is healed. 
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	Concerning the Treatment of an Abscess of Two Tonsils. 
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter Thirty-Six.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	Sometimes there occur between the throat glands, which are called almonds,  that protrude outward; and they are called two tonsils: when you treat these as we have said in division, and they do not heal, then consider. 
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	Therefore if it is an abscess that is hard, dark in color, with little sensation: then do not touch it with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is reddish in color, and its root is thick: then do not touch it even with iron, fearing a flow of blood, but rather let it mature.  
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then either pierce it or it will burst on its own. 
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is white in color, round, and has a slender root: then you must cut into it.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation on it is that before its operation you should consider if the abscess has become quiet, and its heat completely subsided, or whether it diminishes somewhat; then make the sick person sit in front of the sun, and let their head be in your lap; open their mouth, and let a servant take it between his hands and press the tongue down with an instrument, which is shaped as follows.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Let it be made of silver, or of bronze, which is as fine as a knife. 
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	Therefore when you press with it the tongue, and an abscess is shown to you, and your sight falls upon it: then take a hook, and fix it in the amygdala, and draw it forth externally as much as you are able, besides which you draw with it something from the tunics. 
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then incise it with an instrument, of which this is the following form. 
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It is assimilated to forceps: nevertheless the extremities of it are curved, so that the opening of each one of them is directed into the other acutely: whence care should be taken that it is made of tempered iron, or silver imbued with brass. 
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	But if this instrument is not present, then incise it with a scalpel, of which this is the form.  
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	Let it be sharp on one side, not sharp on the other side. 
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you have incised one amygdala, incise the other according to this same kind of incision.  
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the incision let the patient gargle with cold water, or with vinegar and water. 
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there should happen to him a flow of blood, let him gargle with water in which have been boiled the husks of pomegranates: or myrtle leaves, and such like from astringents, until the flow of blood is cut off: then care for it, until it heals.  
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And sometimes there arise in the throat other abscesses, besides the two amygdalae. 
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Therefore incise them according to what I said in the incision of the two amygdalae equally.  
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And I myself indeed have already treated a woman from an abscess, which had arisen between her throat, which was drawing it to a burning, few senses, which already almost closed the throat: and the woman was breathing from a narrow passage, and already prohibited her eating, and drinking water: and already she had arrived at death, if it had remained one day, or two days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the swelling had risen so high that it had sent forth two branches, until they extended beyond the two nostrils. 
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	Therefore I hastened and fixed a hook into one of them. 
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I drew it out, and a large portion was extracted from it.  
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I cut it off where it was grasped from the nostril. 
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I did the same to that which protruded from the other nostril. 
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened her mouth and pressed down her tongue; and afterward I fixed a hook into the swelling itself; then I cut off a portion from it, and only a little blood flowed from it; therefore the woman's throat was healed, and she immediately began to drink water, and then took food.  
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	Therefore I did not cease to cut from that swelling many times over a long period; and the swelling would succeed in the place where I had cut, until it was prolonged excessively and came out with it. 
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I then devised and cauterized the swelling between her throat. 
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	Therefore it stopped from growing; then I departed, and did not know what God did with her after me.  
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	On the Incision of a Swelling of the Palate. 
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter Thirty-Seven. 
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When phlegm descends to the palate and swells up and is long, then it is called perpendicular; and if it is thick and round in the lower part, then it is called a vault. 
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is treated with what we have said in the division and the treatment does not succeed; and you see that the swelling has become quiet and thin from it, then it is necessary to cut into it.  
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And that which is round and gathered from it, and does not have length, and is bloody or tawny colored or black, and has no sensation; then it is necessary to make an incision into it. 
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For there is fear concerning the weak one.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Therefore it is necessary that when you see it according to the manner I have said from its whiteness and length, you should make the weak person sit before the sun, and press their tongue with the instrument of which I have previously spoken; then fix a hook in the uvula and draw it downwards; and cut it with one of the two instruments I mentioned for cutting the two tonsils. 
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And it is necessary that you not cut from it except that which is added beyond the natural term without addition. 
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut from it more, you will injure the voice and speech. 
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision, use that which we have narrated in the incision of the two tonsils; and care for it until it heals. 
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	But if the weak person is frightened by the incision, then it is necessary that you use skill in cauterizing it without fear and dread. 
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the method of cauterization in it is not except with sharp water; and it is, that you place the head of the weak person in your lap. 
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press their tongue with the instrument which we have mentioned. 
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water which I have told you in the chapter on cauterization and mix it with a coal not extinguished, and make it neither thick nor thin, and fill from it the concavity of this instrument, of which this is the shape. 
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Let the extremity in which medicine is placed have a concavity, like the concavity of a radius cochlea.  
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with medicine on the uvula itself; and let the weak person lie on their side so that saliva runs from their mouth out of the inner medicine, so that nothing descends from it to their throat and harms them. 
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine. 
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first place it on the uvula for half an hour, until you see it already blackened and the bite of the medicine subdued. 
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take a piece of cotton and wrap it over the end of the radius, and infuse the cotton with medicine, and introduce the radius with the cotton into the cannula from above, until the cotton adheres onto the tip. 
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do that many times, until you achieve what you desire concerning the cauterization of the vein. 
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then let it alone; for it will dry up and fall off after three days or four. 
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	And if you wish to iterate the medicine, repeat it; and after the cauterization wash around the vein with cotton soaked in butter, and cleanse it of what is around it from the medicine; and bathe it with cold water. 
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And let it be treated externally with embrocations, and internally with gargles, until it is healed. 
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Therefore this kind of treatment is healthier than incision and further from danger.  
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes a vein is also treated with something more subtle than cautery and incision; for it is treated with fumigation, in this manner.
