Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamus, and hyssop, and origanum, and rue, and sage, and chamomile, and abrotanum, and things like them from herbs; and gather all these together, or some of them in a pot, and submerge them with vinegar, and let them boil; and the pot should be plastered well with clay; and there should be a hole in the middle of the pot, above which an instrument concave in shape is placed. 
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made of silver or bronze; and insert the extremity, in which there is a pomegranate, into the mouth of the sick person, until the vapor rises to the vein above the cannula, until the vein becomes very dark.  
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat it over it many times, until it dries up. 
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And be careful not to do this treatment at the beginning of the arrival of an abscess. 
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For it usually adds to the abscess; and it is not right for you to do this unless at the decline of its heat.  
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If you do not have this instrument present, then take a tube and put bark on the end of it so that the mouth of the sick person is not burned; for the bark prevents vapor from burning the mouth; and this is good healing with safety. 
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the Extraction of Thorns and Bones from the Throat. 
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter Thirty-Eight. 
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Very often a bone or a fishbone, or something else adheres in the throat. 
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore you must extract what is apparent from them upon which vision falls after you press the tongue with an instrument toward the sun, and it is declared to you what is in the throat. 
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, you must make the sick person vomit before the food is digested in the stomach. 
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	For perhaps the attached thing will go out through vomiting. 
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or let the sick person swallow a piece of turnip or a lettuce root, or swallow a mouthful of dry bread; or take a piece of dried gentle sea sponge and tie it with thread, then swallow it. 
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When it reaches the place where the spines or bone are, and they are extracted, then they come out.  
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not come out with what we have said, then use an instrument of lead according to this form. 
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be somewhat thicker than a spoke and let there be a curve at the end of it, so that it may enter his throat easily; and let him have his head elevated upward. 
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And be careful of touching his epiglottis so that coughing does not happen to him and he drives out the bone or spine with it, or let the doctor introduce it with his own hand. 
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But for the sick person to introduce it is better: because of his knowledge of the location of the attached thing; and he drives it down or pulls his hand upward with the instrument, all of it according to the quantity that is prepared for him until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the Extraction of a Leech. 
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX. 
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When a leech is treated with what I have said in the division on healing with medicines and it does not detach, then consider in the throat of the sick person in front of the sun, or by the sun after you press its tongue with an instrument which I have described to you. 
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your sight falls upon the leech, extract it with a small hook, or with delicate forceps discreetly. 
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	And if this is not possible with them: then take a concave cannula and insert it into the throat of the sick person up to near the throat; then insert iron heated with fire into the concavity of the cannula. 
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this many times, and let the sick person abstain from all water for a whole day. 
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a goblet full of cold water and open his mouth into it; and moisten his mouth with it and not swallow anything from it; and stir the water with his hand one hour after another. 
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the leech immediately, when it feels the water, falls off. 
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if it does not depart with what we have described, then fumigate the sick person with bedbugs, or with asafoetida with an instrument which I have described in the fumigation of the uvula. 
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, for it will fall off.  
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the manner of operation in fumigation is to take a pot in which there are live prunes with fire; and let the pot be covered with a lid, in the middle of which there is a hole; and let the extremity of the instrument be placed into that hole. 
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then project the fumigation and let the sick person place his mouth at the extremity of the cannula and close his mouth so that the fumigation does not escape until you know that the fumigation has already reached the leech. 
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will immediately fall off. 
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not fall out, then repeat the fumigation many times. 
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the sick person endure thirst, and eat salt things, and garlic, and let him not drink water. 
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he goes out with this regimen. 
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which the leech is extracted from the throat when it falls upon it by sight. 
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to forceps, as you see: except that it has this curvature which is inserted into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And the extremity of it is similar to the beak of a bird which is called a stork, in which there is roughness like a file: when it grasps something, it does not release it at all. 
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	Concerning the opening of abscesses, and their incision, and care in general.  
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of abscesses, of many ways, according to what comes to the recollection of them, namely one, and one in this book: and they are different in their perforation, and incision of themselves in two ways. 
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of which is from the kind of abscess itself, and that because it comprises from humidities.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second way is on account of the places, in which it happens in the body. 
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Because an abscess happening in the head is different from an abscess happening in the anus: and an abscess happening in a fleshy place is different from an abscess happening in joints: and to each of them there is a judgment of its own from the operation. 
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from abscesses there are which ought not to be perforated except after the maturation of blood in them, and its completion; and from them there are which ought to be perforated while they are raw, and do not mature according to completion.  
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Such as abscesses which are near joints. 
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Because an abscess when it happens near a joint, and is prolonged to be its own, until it putrefies what is in its circumference perhaps the ligaments, or nerves of that joint are corrupted: therefore there is a cause for the closer contraction of that member.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Either there is an abscess at a major limb; for if you delay its incision until it matures, it will harm either that limb or the main limb through it. 
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is near the anus, therefore perforate it while immature; and it is not necessary to perforate an abscess crude, of incomplete digestion, except that which is near the anus, lest it putrefy deeply, and extend to the interior of the anus, and a fistula be formed, or a termination thereof which does not heal. 
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You ought to know the hour of incision of an abscess, which is matured according to completeness; and it is at sedation of pain, recession of fever, and diminution of redness, and throbbing, and sharpness of the head of the abscess; and the remaining signs. 
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And it is necessary that you make the same incision in the lower part of the abscess, and of more vehement eminency; and let the incision be wading in length according to the body, if the abscesses are in parts of the hands and feet, and places of muscles, and chords, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all equal places where there is no reflection. 
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But in those which are reflected, wade with the incision according to that limb. 
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	But when an abscess is in fleshy places; then it is better that you dismiss its incision until its digestion is confirmed, as we said according to completeness. 
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you perforate it before that, the course of the virus is prolonged from it, and there is much filth and foulness, and perhaps its lips will become hardened, and its depth. 
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And certain abscesses are perforated according to the breadth of the body according to necessity; or according to that in which the limb needs. 
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you administer a small incision in small abscesses, and a large incision in large abscesses; or many sections through similarity to the magnitude of the abscess.  
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And they are from abscesses, in which the skin must be concave; and it should be cut when it has become like cloth, and has been made at the end, which is already dead: just as happens in many, such as boils and buboes. 
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And of these are those which are cut with a section having three angles. 
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And of these is one, from which it is cut like the shape of a myrtle leaf. 
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Such as an abscess of the groin. 
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And of these are those in which a round section and a lunar section are administered; and similar to them from sections.  
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	But that which has no head, such as mild superficial abscesses, must be perforated with a superficial perforation or only flat. 
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And when the abscess is large and has already collected much pus and you perforate it, do not hurry and draw out all the pus in that hour; rather, draw out a part of it.  
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then close the abscess until another day. 
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then again draw out something of the pus. 
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to gradation, until it comes out; especially if the patient is weak in strength, or a pregnant woman, or a small child, or an old man who has grown weak; for indeed the animal spirit is often resolved from the animal with the outflow of pus; and perhaps the sick person dies, and you do not perceive it. 
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore beware of this chapter with great caution.  
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have perforated these abscesses, it is necessary that you wash the wound; and consider. 
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	Therefore if the wound of the abscess is small, or it is a flat section, then apply a bandage from linen or old cotton.  
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if the abscess is large and there are many fissures of the perforation, it is necessary then to insert a bandage into every fissure until they reach each other. 
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if in an abscess you have cut off a part of the skin, or have scooped it out around its circumference: then it is necessary that you fill it with old lint, or as when cloth is woven, or shaved with flax down without moisture; and bind it up until the third day. 
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then loosen it, and care for it with what is necessary from ointment, until it heals. 
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if bleeding should happen during your operation, then administer cold water and vinegar, after a cloth has been soaked in them; and place it upon the place of the bleeding many times. 
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the bleeding should persist, then it is necessary that you administer a regimen and care, and powders which I have described in many places of this book of ours, and by division. 
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is in the time of winter, and the place of the abscess is of many nerves: then it is necessary that you pour warm broth with wine and oil; and place them upon the places. 
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it should be in summer, and the places are fleshy: then it is necessary that you place broth soaked in water and oil, or in wine and oil, and all of it cold. 
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until when it will be the third day, as we said, then it is necessary that you loosen the abscess, and wash it out, and administer in its care what suits it, until it heals. 
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This, therefore, is what is necessary from knowledge of treatment of abscesses universally.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the way of distinction, I have now spoken of every abscess, how its way to cure is taken up individually. 
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Concerning the incision of abscesses which occur in the skin of the head.  
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41. 
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small abscesses occur in the skin of the head, and they are of a species of nodules, which contain sheaths, which are sacs to them: as if they themselves were like pouches of a hen. 
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of them. 
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Among them are some that are fatty; and among them are some that contain moisture like mud; and among them are some that contain moisture like curdled milk and pulps; and those similar to them; and among them are some that are hard and stony. 
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the section of all of them, and their extraction, there is no fear, as long as the artery does not make resistance at their section. 
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their section is that you try them with an instrument, whose form comes after this, which is called an Intromissum, until you know what it contains. 
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it is that which contains moisture, then dry it by a section according to its length with a superficial section, according to this form. 
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with a section from line b to line g.  Therefore when the moisture is evacuated, then the skin kistin which contains it, and do not let anything remain within it. 
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For very often it returns if anything remains within it. 
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the stump in Egyptian ointment if it is present; and if not, in water and salt; and fill the wound with it, and leave it until another day. 
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it will corrode what remained from the kist.  
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat upon the stump with a second, and third Egyptian ointment, and if it does not yield to that, until you are confident that nothing remained from the kist, then care for the wound with ointment until it heals. 
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	But if the abscess contains a fatty node, then dry it according to this form, with a section having the form of a cross; and project hooks between the two lips of the section, and skin it from every side; and exert your strength in extracting the tunic which contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if the artery makes resistance to you, then do what I will tell you afterward.  
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And do likewise for an abscess, if it is stony, from incision and treatment the same as we have said. 
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And incision over a stony abscess is easier because there is little blood and moisture. 
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are certain of these abscesses which are in the head in some people with which there is no moisture at all. 
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	Which is because I cut into an abscess on the head of a young woman and found the abscess like a solid and hard stone, rough and white, which could not be broken; and if one should strike it with a projectil it would wound the person. 
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	But in other abscesses occurring in the head, besides these abscesses which occur in the heads of infants and at the roots of ears, the incision of all of them should be a superficial incision.  
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make a puncture of them always from their lower part so that the course of blood is relieved downwards. 
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then treat it with what suits them from its treatment.  
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Concerning the incision of strangles in the neck. 
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Very often these abscesses occur in the neck and under the armpits and groins; and sometimes they occur in the rest of the body. 
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And those that occur from them in the neck are one and many and they are generated from each other; and every strangles from them is within its own tunic as it is in nodes and abscesses of the head as we have described. 
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of these strangles. 
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	For some of them are stony and some contain moisture and some are malignant, which do not obey treatment. 
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	Therefore in that one which you see from them of good disposition to the touch, of which it is clear that it is close to the color of the skin and moves to every part, and is not joined with the nerves of the neck, nor the gland, nor the artery and is not deep: it is necessary that you cut it with a superficial incision from the upper part to the lower part of the body from line b. to line g. and flay it from all sides; and extend two lips of skin with a hook or hooks if needed as we said in abscesses of the head, and extract it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is a precaution, that a vein or nerve not be cut. 
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the knife be not very sharp, so that it does not add to your hand with the incision, nor agitate the sick person, and you may cut what is not necessary. 
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut a vein or artery, or it prevents you from the operation, then put into the wound a boiled herb, or certain powders that staunch blood, and constrict the wound, and let it be until the sharpness of the inflammation subsides, and the wound softens: or it begins to become putrid. 
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is staunched by a tunic. Return therefore to your operation until you complete it. 
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your index finger if anything remains from the little styptics or others: therefore cut them and clean them. 
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	But if there is in the root of a stypsis a large vein: then it is necessary that you not cut that stypsis from its root: but rather that you tie it with a strong doubled thread, and let it be until it falls off by itself without harm. 
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with old lint, which you have already submerged in Egyptian ointment.  
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of it. 
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	But if the whole stypsis is cut, then it is necessary that you bring together the two lips of the wound: and sew it immediately after you see that there is no surplus remaining at all. 
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that there is a surplus remaining because of the size of the stypsis, then it is necessary that you intend to cut its root and extract it: and apply the suture as we have said. 
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And that which contains moisture from the styptics, pierce it with a superficial perforation so that the place of its maturity appears to you: and place the perforation from what follows below the body as we have said. 
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the perforation linen with ointment and things similar to them so that it corrodes what remains from the corruption until when you see that the wound is already cleansed: then take care of it with a generative ointment of flesh until it heals. 
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the incision of the epiglottis affected by an abscess within the throat. 
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII. 
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients spoke of this incision in the epiglottis, and I have not seen anyone in our land who has done it; and this is the writing of their words. 
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in those who have fluxion, the epiglottis must be incised when there is no benefit from that; because all the veins and lungs are weak. 
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	But in those who have a hot abscess in the mouth, or throat, or both tonsils, when there is no pain in the canal, the epiglottis must be incised to avoid the destruction which results from premonition. 
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we wish to do this, we must cut the epiglottis below three or four circles of the epiglottis, with a small incision in width, in that which is between the two circles by an amount that makes the incision in the flesh, not in the cartilage; and indeed this place is suitable for the incision because it is private to flesh, and blood vessels are far from it. 
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	But if the physician is timid, then he must extend the skin of the throat with a hook.  
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then let him pierce the skin until he reaches the canal; divert the blood vessels if he sees anything from them. 
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then let him cut the flesh as we have described; and it is indicated above the incision of the canal by phlegm which issues from it, with what is broken up, and cessation of voice.  
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave the wound open for a time. 
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	Therefore when the hour is removed in which premonition is feared, join the two lips of the skin wound and sew it alone without cartilage. 
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines that cause flesh to grow until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis.	Says Albucasis.  
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The sum of this discourse which we have narrated is not exposition except when they see that some of these apostemata already has suppurated the throat of the sick person and he is raised up on the point of death and desires to intercept his breaths: they go to cutting the epiglottis so that the sick person may breathe upon the place of the wound with a certain respiration and be saved from death; and for this reason they ordered to leave the wound open until the malice of the sickness is consumed and it is the malice of this three days and as if itself: then therefore they ordered to sew the wound and to heal it until it heals. 
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I myself saw was that a certain handmaid took a knife and sent it into her throat and it fell upon a part of the pulmonary canal.  
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to her healing and I found her moaning like is the moan of a dead person. 
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I therefore examined from the wound and I found little blood which had issued from the wound.  
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I was therefore perplexed because she had not cut a vein nor her gullet and wind was coming out from the wound. 
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I therefore hastened and sewed up her wound and healed it until it was well and nothing happened to the handmaid except hoarseness in her voice and she returned after days to a better disposition of hers.  
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	From this therefore I say that there is no fear in the cutting of the epiglottis. 
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	Concerning the cutting of a hernia of the throat.  
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter Forty-Four.  
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This swelling called a hernia of the throat is a large swelling according to the color of the body and it is much in women. 
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is according to two ways either it is natural or accidental.  
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural there is certainly no craft. 
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental however is according to two ways of which one is similar to fatty nodes.  
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	Another method is similar to an abscess which occurs from tying off an artery. 
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is fear within it, and it is not fitting that presumption be made against it with iron except in that which is small; and you test it, and investigate it with an Intromisso. 
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If therefore you find it similar to a fat knot, and it is not suspended with any veins: then cut it off, as knots are cut; and extract it with that which it contains from the cyst, if it is in a cyst: and if not, then scrutinize its entirety. 
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with what is fitting from healing, until it heals. 
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On the Section of Different Kinds of Knots.  
Caput XLV.	Chapter Forty-Five. 
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of knots, and I have already said all their kinds in the division; and it is fitting that I tell here the difference between a Knot and an Excrescence: since there is a doubt-causing one. 
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore that when there is an Excrescence there is heat, and fever, and violent pains until the boiling of superfluity is calmed, and putrefaction is completed; then indeed fever and heat subside.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But with a Knot there is no heat, nor fever, nor pain; and they contain them in cysts sifachin, which are their own sac, and it is according to the color of the body; and its beginning is like a pea, and it becomes like a date-stone, larger and smaller. 
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are according to two kinds: either fatty or containing moisture.  
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of moisture are many, according to what I said in the division. 
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore it is fitting that when you come to the healing of a Knot, that you experiment on it, and inquire into it first with an instrument called an Intromisso, according to how its form will come in the chapter which follows this. 
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of inquiry for abscesses, and all Knots, is to take this instrument, and insert it into the moister place which you find in the abscess; and you revolve your fingers with it gradually, until you know that the instrument has already penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then place your last finger according to the measurement of the size of the abscess. 
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then extract the intrument and consider that which comes out in its wake. 
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	Therefore if flowing moisture emerges, whatever its color may be: then dry it with a superficial incision, as I have said in other abscesses. 
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if moisture does not emerge in the wake of the instrument, then know that it is thick: therefore dry it above with an incision in the shape of a cross, according to this form as I have taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and flay the skin from every part with ease: and keep the plaster if you are able upon it so that you extract it whole with its knot. 
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	But if the cyst ruptures during the operation and it is not possible to extract it whole, for this often happens, then extract it in pieces until nothing remains of it. 
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if a little or a lot remains of it, the knot will return for the most part. 
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	And if it overcomes you and a little remains from it: then fill the wound upon completion with certain corrosive and sharp powders: and constrict the wound and place above it what sits upon the abscess hot, and care for it with the remaining treatment until it is healed. 
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	Therefore if the knot is large, then sew its two lips together, and care for it as it heals.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if there is a vein contrary to you, pulsatile or not pulsatile: then hurry and fill the place with finely ground triturated matter, and let it remain constricted for two or three days until the wound putrefies and the boiling of the blood subsides: then return to incise what remains from the knot.  
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Concerning external instruments for incision and perforation. 
Caput XLVI.	Chapter Forty-Six. 
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	Among them are the forms of instruments, and they are of three kinds.  
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For from them is a great one, and from them is a medium one, and from them is a small one. 
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let them be made of well-tempered iron with square ends, so that they hasten entry into the abscess.  
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of Instruments, and namely, piercing; and one of them is called a bistoury, that is, a piercer; and they are of three kinds. 
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For from them is a great one, a medium one, and a small one. 
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They are suited to investigate abscesses through them, and outlets, and fistulas, and buboes from what is between bones. 
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, smooth, gentle, like large needles with which sutures are taken, namely from brass, or bronze, or iron, or silver. 
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the better ones of them are those made from brass.  
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And Instruments are also made of black lead, which are suitable so that fistulas may be investigated through them, with which there are reflections due to their concavity, so that they may be reflected gently with those reflections. 
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And they are again of three kinds. 
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For from them are long ones, from them medium ones, and from them short ones, according to the quantity of the width of the fistula and its tightness. 
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of Hooks, and they are of many kinds. 
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For from them are simple ones, namely those which have a single curve; and they are of three kinds as you see, Large, Medium, and Small. 
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from them are blind Hooks; and they are of three kinds.  
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from them are Hooks having two curves, and they are of three kinds; and from them are Hooks having three curves, and they are of three kinds; and all these are necessary in their place.  
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of Knives, with which nodes and abscesses are cut and pared; and they are of three kinds: for from them is a great one, a medium one, and a small one.  
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities by which the section is made are sharp, other extremities are not sharp; and they are not put thus, except so that with them refreshment may be made in the excision of nodes at fear of incision of a vein or nerve; and that he who is ill may be healed by them, and find a little tranquility from the burning which he finds in the excision of an abscess. 
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are magda, and they are of three kinds. 
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of metal, and are similar to a Radiator, with which alcohol is made; and at the wide end there is a hidden Spatula point: and it runs to the inside, and outside when you wish, as you see. 
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shape of the spatulas which are hidden between the fingers at the excision of abscesses: and the sick do not perceive them: and they are of three kinds, large, medium, and small. 
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	Shapes of Suction Cups with which the flow of blood is cut off; and they are of three kinds, large, medium, and small. 
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of metal or brass, round, a little in length as you see; and let them be delicate. 
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of Suction Cups be large and small with you so that you may cut off blood quickly when needed and then when medicine is not present for you.  
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, do not use them in the cutting off of blood in every place of the body, and do not use them except in fleshy places: such as the calves of the leg, and the hip, and the calves of the arms, and the breasts, and the belly, and the groin, and similar ones, from fleshy calves, moist.  
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes other small instruments are made from them similar to pistachio shells according to their shape; with which blood is cut off when it flows from the place of phlebotomy or at the incision of a vein or artery: and sometimes they are made round according to this shape.  
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the treatment of the mammary glands of men which resemble those of women. 
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII. 
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the nipples of certain men swell up during sleep, until they resemble women's breasts, and they remain foul abscesses. 
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	He who wishes to get rid of this should make a crescent-shaped incision above the nipples, from line b to line g. Then he should remove all the skin and fat. 
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Afterwards fill the wound with flesh-producing medicine.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound with sutures and care for it until it heals. 
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the nipple hangs down and softens because of its size, as happens to women: then it is necessary to make two incisions on its upper sides, similar in shape to a crescent moon, each contained with the other at the ends of both, until there is a larger line containing the smaller one, according to this form from line b. to line g. Afterwards remove the skin which is between the two lips and take away the fat, and apply what we said about sutures and powders, which are necessary for healing, until it heals. 
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	But if you cannot complete the incision as needed because of the patient's restlessness or the flow of blood: then you must fill the wound with cotton soaked in a corrosive ointment and leave it until it corrodes what remains of the fat. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals. 
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	On the perforation of an abscess which occurs under the nipple. 
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII. 
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses which occur under the nipple are of a hard kind like a Strophulus, which contain cysts and those which contain moisture. 
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Those therefore which are of the kind that contain moisture, should be cut with a crescent-shaped incision, according to this form, from line b to line g. When all that is in the abscess has been evacuated as pus, then fill it with old cotton and leave it until the next day. 
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then let the shirt be removed, and let it be treated with a suitable ointment until it is healed. 
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	But if the abscess is of the type of knotty Strophulus, then cut it above it, as we said in the section on Strophulus equally. 
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	But if the wound extends so as to discharge pus, then apply a cautery to it, according to what we have said before. 
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On the section of an abscess which occurs due to Artery and Vein. 
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured and the skin above it becomes consolidated, then an abscess often occurs from this; and similarly it happens with a vein, so that an abscess and swelling occur in it. 
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that an abscess and swelling are due to an artery and vein are: because when the abscess is due to an artery, it is long, gathered deep in the body; and when you press the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there is a rasping sound. 
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to a vein is round, manifest on the body.  
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section of this abscess is an error and especially that which is under the armpits and groins and neck and in many places on the body; and it is very large. 
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, its treatment must be divided with iron, and what is also from them in the extremities, or in the head, must be divided. 
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore, on that which is from them by inflation of the orifice of the artery, make a section in the skin lengthwise.  
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with hooks, then the artery; and free it from its tunics until it is exposed.  
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert a needle under it and make it penetrate up to the other side, and tie the artery with a double thread in two places, according to what I have taught you in the extraction of the two arteries that are in the temples. 
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then puncture the place which is between the two ligaments with a trocar, until all the blood contained within it comes out, and the abscess is resolved. 
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply a treatment that produces pus, until the ligaments fall away; afterwards treat it with suitable ointments, until it heals. 
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	But if the abscess is due to a vein being cut, then you must hold with your hand as much of the abscess with the skin as possible. 
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert a needle under the place which you held with your hand and make it penetrate; and let there be a double thread in it until you draw it out from the other side. 
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie with it the abscess with a good ligament; according to what I told you in the vein ligament, from two parts with two ends of thread. 
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	But if you fear that the thread will be pulled out, then insert another needle with another thread under the whole abscess at the puncture; press and tighten your threads in four places.  
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the abscess in its middle, until what is inside it comes out; then cut away the excess skin and release what was tied from it. 
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place upon it a poultice which you have soaked in wine and oil.  
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply treatment, made with licorice and ointments until it heals. 
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	Concerning an abscess which occurs from the twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter I.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess occurs in arteries and veins, similarly an abscess occurs in nerves; which happens to them through a blow or from excessive labor and similar causes; and it most often occurs in those places where the limbs join, such as the heel, and in every place where the joints are moved, and the abscess is severe.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color resembles the rest of the body, and it is in many positions without pain; and when it is squeezed with force, a weak sensation similar to numbness is felt within it.  
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not a gathered abscess deep within the body, but rather under the skin, and itself moves to every part, and does not go forward, nor before, nor backward to the rear. 
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore, that which is from them in the joints should not be invaded with iron. 
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	For perhaps a contraction may occur. 
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But that which is from them in the head or forehead, cut the skin with a scalpel.  
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	And if therefore it is a small abscess, then hold it with forceps and cut it from the root. 
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook and flay it: then remove it and gather the wound with sutures: and tend to it until it heals. 
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Concerning the incision of an abscess which occurs in the abdomen.
Caput LI.	Chapter LI. 
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	It happens to some men many times in their bellies and in the other parts of their bodies, boils which are called fungal, by similarity to fungi. 
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	The root of which is subtle, and the head is thick, and their lips are inverted. 
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And there are some small ones from them, and there are some that greatly enlarge.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I myself have indeed already seen a man, and in his belly were two boils which were more like fungi than anything else: there was no difference between them, white, of a small root, and their lips were inverted, and they split open, and moisture always flowed from them. 
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	Therefore I cut into them and found in the weight of one almost ten and eight ounces and in the other almost six ounces. And the operation in their incision is that you consider then if he is weak and moist and the color of the boil is white, moist, of a delicate root: then cut it with a broad scalpel, and have a cautery present with you in the fire. 
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For very often much blood is expelled at its incision; therefore hasten and if blood overcomes you, then cauterize it. 
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	But if you see a weak and timid person from the incision with a knife, then take a thread made of lead properly, and bind it with that thread: whose method is what we said, and let him go for two days. 
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add lead to the ligature. 
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore do not cease binding the lead whenever it presses into the wound, until it is cut off and falls by itself without labor. 
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if the wart has a thick root, then there is some fear and dread in its incision; especially because it is on the abdomen. 
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However it is possible to cut into half of it.  
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not return. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for it until the wound heals. 
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware that you do not presume to cut into a wart which is of a dark color, with little sensation, and an ugly appearance; for it is indeed a cancerous abscess; and I will come with the remembrance of Cancer after this.  
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the care of the prominence of the navel. 
Caput LII.	Chapter Fifty-Two.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	The prominence of the navel arises from many causes.  
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from fissures of the omentum, which is over the abdomen; and there issues forth fat, or intestine, according to what happens in other ruptures. 
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood flowing from a vein, or an artery, according to what has been said previously. 
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from wind compressed within it. 
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	But if it is due to a fissure of the omentum and the issuing forth of fat; then its color resembles the color of the body; and it is soft, without pain; and appears in various locations.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the protrusion of intestine, then its location is, along with what we have described, of a more violent diversity.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When therefore you press it with your fingers, it is concealed; then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it; and it magnifies greatly at the entrance of the bath, and a vehement labor. 
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	But if it is on account of humidity, it is soft, then it is not concealed when you press it with your hand, nor does it become constricted, nor is anything added. 
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	But if it is on account of blood, then with these signs an abscess appears tending to blackness from the clefts. 
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	But if it is on account of flesh that has formed, then the abscess is heavy, thick, hard, and it is fixed according to a single quantity. 
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	But if it is on account of windiness, then its touch is soft.  
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the procedure in that case is, that you then consider whether the prominence of the navel is on account of blood from an Artery or Vein, or windiness; then it is necessary that you forbid its treatment. 
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For there is fear and dread, as I taught you in the chapter in which I said abscesses are on account of artery and vein. 
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	But if the prominence of the navel is on account of intestine or membrane; then it is necessary that you direct the sick person to hold his breath and stand upright extended. 
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then mark with sealing wax all around the circumference of the navel.  
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then direct him to lie down between your hands on his back. 
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then encircle with a broad spatula around the navel upon the place which you marked with sealing wax.  
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the middle of the abscess upward with a large hook. 
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie it around firmly with thread or a cord made of silk with a strong binding; and let the knot of the ligament be away from the constriction. 
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the extended middle of the abscess above the ligature.  
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If then you find it already caught by a ligament: then extract the alenxotati, and insert the index finger into it, and push the intestine towards the interior of the abdomen; and if you find a zirbum, then take it up with a hook, and cut away its excess. 
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if it is an artery or vein to the contrary, then bind it very much. 
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation. 
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and insert into them two strong threads; and insert the two needles into the circumference which you made around the apostema in the manner of a cross, which you make penetrate. 
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then constrict the apostema in four places over the needles; and if you wish, remove the needles, and leave the place until the extended flesh rots; and falls off by itself: or cut it when it softens and decays. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what is necessary from ointments, until it heals. 
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	But if the eminence of the umbilicus is from fleshous growth in it, or from moisture: then it is necessary that you make concave apostemas, as we have said. 
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And draw out the blood or moisture which you find in it. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then treat it with what strengthens the place.  
¶ De cura CANCRI.	Concerning the Care of CANCER. 
Caput LIII.	Chapter Fifty-Three. 
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken in the division of the species of Cancer, and how is the way to its cure with medicines; and we warned against it when curing it with iron, so as not to ulcerate it: and we spoke about Cancer generated in the womb, and cautioned against its treatment. 
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that sometimes Cancer is in a place where it is possible to eradicate it; such as Cancer which is in the breasts, or in the thigh, and those similar to them, from the limbs located for extracting all of it; especially when it is beginning and small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When it is old and large, you should not approach it closely. 
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I myself was unable to heal anyone from it, nor did I see anyone before me who had succeeded in doing so.  
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation on it, when it is located as we have said, is to precede and loosen the weak part from the black bile several times. 
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then phlebotomy itself if you find it with manifest fullness.  
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the weak part with preparation in which it will be placed during the operation. 
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then introduce into the cancer hooks that are suitable for it.  
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then scoop it out from every part with the skin, according to careful examination, until nothing remains of its roots; and let the blood flow, and do not cut it off quickly, rather press the locations and wipe away all thick blood with your hand, or with whatever instrument is possible there. 
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if the flow of thick blood from the incision of an artery or vein opposes you, then cauterize the vein until the blood is cut off. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remaining treatment until it is healed.  
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	Concerning the treatment of Hydropsy. 
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIV.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We have already explained in the division the kinds of hydropsy, and how the gathering of water occurs; and the signs of each kind, and its treatment with medicine.  
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is treated with iron is only the kind of ascites alone; and it does not approach the kind of tympanitis with iron, nor the kind of hydrosarca deeply; for that is fatal. 
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this kind of hydropsy, tympanitis with medicine, and your medication has not been successful, then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.
