Deinde intromitte tentam cum filo in Fistulam, donec consequatur concauitatem eius.	Then insert the probe with the thread into the fistula until it reaches its concavity.  
Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If therefore it is penetrating into the inner margin of the anus nearby, then draw out the thread from that hole: so that you insert your finger into the anus and draw out the end of the thread, and join the two ends together: and tighten both, and leave it for one day or two days: and the more the thread falls into the flesh, tighten it well until those pieces of flesh between the two ends of the thread fall off; then care for the wound until it is consolidated and healed. 
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	But if the opening of the fistula is not penetrating: then make it penetrate by any means that is prepared for you, unless it is very deep. 
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	For it is not fitting for you to do that because of tearing, so that you do not fall into it.
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	Then do with it as we said until it is healed. 
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	The form of a sharp-pointed speculum with which the fistula is divided, whose curvature is very sharp and the other part is not sharp so that it does not fall into what is not necessary as you see. 
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	On the suture of hemorrhoids, from which blood flows from their incision; and care for fissures. 
Caput LXXXI.	Chapter Eighty-One. 
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	There are hemorrhoids according to two types. 
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	For they are either within the anus, like bladders of charcoal or prunes; or as if they themselves are grains of a pomegranate. 
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	And from them there are small ones, and large ones: and blood flows from them always, and is one, and are many. 
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	And they are outside the anus, and at its extremities.
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	But those which are outside the anus are according to most few in moisture, from which runs watery fluid, or a little blood with constant flow; and they are according to the color of the body.
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	And the treatment of that which is within the anus, is that you order the sick person to strain; and it should be squeezed until the anus protrudes, and hemorrhoids appear to you.  
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore suspend them with hooks; or hold them with your fingernail. 
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then cut into them at their roots.
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	But if hooks do not hold them because of their moisture and softness; then take them with a rough cloth or a swab from double wool, and pull them out with your fingers. 
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut into them, and sprinkle over them after the incision certain hot powders so that they will serve as a cautery for them. 
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them according to what preceded in the chapter on cauterization.
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with the remaining treatment until they are healed. 
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	But if the anus does not yield to protrusion, then give the sick person an enema in which there is a little mordant, so that it washes with what is in the anus, and yields to protrusion quickly when the sick person strains.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	But if hemorrhoids are external from the anus, then their matter is light, easy; and it is as you take them with your fingernail or take them with a hook, and cut into them.
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we have said until they are healed. 
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And whoever recoils from cutting with iron, then it is necessary that you administer a suture to them according to this method. 
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take an unraveled thread and insert it into the needle. 
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then draw the thread upwards through the needle and make it penetrate with the point at its root on one side; and wind the two ends of the thread around the lower part of the needle so that they are parallel to each other, and tighten the thread firmly with a strong knot. 
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then tie off the thread and remove the needle. 
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the threads and leave one of them untied, so that excess blood may run from it.  
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place a cloth soaked in rose oil or carrot oil on top of the wound and put it over the area; and instruct the patient to rest. 
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then leave him until it falls off. 
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When therefore the threads fall off, care for them with ointments and the rest of the treatment until they are healed.  
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	On the Treatment of Fissures. 
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	Very often they occur from drying of excrement and constriction of nature.  
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	Therefore when they become chronic and medicine is not effective in them; then it is necessary that you scrape them with the point of a scalpel or with your fingernail until they become moist, and remove the top layer which prevents them from consolidating. 
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for them until they consolidate as is necessary.  
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	But if they do not consolidate; then repeat them with a more vigorous scraping than the first until they bleed profusely and are flayed; then care for them until they are healed.  
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	On the Treatment of Hemorrhoids, Both Inverted and Non-Inverted, and Threads, as Well as Ants. 
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter Eighty-Two.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	Know that a hemorrhoid is nothing but a round knot according to the color of the body, similar to the head of a nail; and it occurs throughout the entire body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and toes; and pain results from them upon walking. 
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	Therefore it must be cut what is around the clavicle, and held with forceps or a hook, and eradicated from its root. 
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then care for that; and if you wish, cauterize it according to what preceded in its chapter.  
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	From the ash-tree however there is one small eminence, rough, filtered, round above the surface of the body. 
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And it often happens in the hands of children. 
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And the treatment for it is, to extend the ash tree and cut it; or tie it with silk thread; or with a hair until it falls off. 
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what was previously mentioned with fire or with a sharp medicine; and now inverted ash trees are eradicated, and non-inverted ones with the instrument which I will say.  
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	An ant however is also a small eminence, filtered, thick, above the surface of the body, extending deep; and when it finds cold, it feels like an ant bite therein, and this happens throughout the whole body; and most of it occurs in the hands. 
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its treatment is, to take a cannula from a goose feather, or a vulture quill strong; and place that cannula upon the ant, until the circle of the cannula contains its parts. 
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then revolve your hand with the cannula until you cut what is around the ant; and place it deep into the flesh and eradicate the ant from its root. 
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, do this with an air or iron cannula, according to this form.  
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the upper part of the cannula be a loose winding, drawing upwards, so that the apprehension thereof and its revolution is relieved upon the finger. 
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you wish, cauterize the ant according to what was previously mentioned in the cauterization of the ash tree in the chapter on cautery. 
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	Concerning the forms of instruments which are used for fistulas in diseases of the anus, and rupture of the abdomen, and colic. 
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter Eighty-Three. 
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	Sometimes an enema is made of silver, or of brass, or of cast bronze, or hammered bronze. 
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And sometimes it is made of these instruments small and large, according to those in which they are administered.  
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	Therefore, that which is administered in the healing of very young children should be small; and those whose anuses are weak, or painful, so also their enemas.  
Clistere magnum.	A large enema. 
Cistere paruum.	A small enema. 
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	The tube of it, that is, the upper head in which the bladder is tied, should be wide according to this manner: and let there be a distinction so that the bladder is tied as you see, and its lower extremity which is inserted into the anus, should be blunt, that is, not open, smooth, very slender, drawing toward subtlety; and on one of its sides there shall be two holes, and on the other side one hole. 
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	And let the width of the hole be according to the thickness of the rays, and a little thicker; and let the bladder in which the medicines are placed be from the bladder of an animal; or from sheepskin parchment, which shall be according to the form of a small wineskin: the root of which shall be one palm. 
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And let it be pierced with many holes as it is revolved, and the space which is between every hole shall be the thickness of a finger.  
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into those holes a strong thread from raw silk, which shall be from ten threads or about that, and combine it with a bladder like that of a wineskin. 
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When therefore the bladder is placed in it, tighten at the head of the enema between two distinctions with a strong constriction.  
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then administer the enema with it. 
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the form of the circle of bladders here depicted, and the holes. 
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of giving an enema with it is to fill a syringe or bladder with medicine that has been warmed according to the amount the sick person can tolerate; and be careful that it is not very hot nor very cold. 
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the sick person is laid on their back and raises their legs upwards; and put something under them, that is, leather on which people lie, or a sheet. 
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then smear the end of the enema with oil, or with egg white, or with fenugreek mucilage, or something similar. 
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then gently insert it into the anus. 
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then let the attendant hold the syringe with both hands at the same time and squeeze it vigorously until all that is in the enema is emptied into the intestine.
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then remove the enema and let the sick person raise their legs up to the wall. 
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If the medicine compels them to defecate, then let them hold it as long as they can.  
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if they sleep with it all night, it is best for healing. 
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	But if you give an enema to someone with abdominal swelling and they rush to defecate, then repeat the enema until they are healed. 
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	But if there are hemorrhoids or painful abscesses in the anus, then let the enema be very mild and gentle, like the enemas given to children.  
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of a delicate enema for when the skin is tight. 
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On the Treatment of Head Wounds Without Bone Fracture.  
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter 84. 
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already said in the division on the treatment of wounds what was fitting for the book, and I will say here the treatment of them with the hand and with medicines according to complement.  
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	Therefore I say that wounds are diversified according to what causes the wound and according to the place on which the wound falls. 
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	Therefore, the things by which wounds are often made are like the throwing of a stone: or a cut with a sword, or knife; or a percussion with a spear, or wood, or arrow; and similar things from many objects. 
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	But wounds which are made according to the locations of the body are, such as a wound which falls upon the head, or neck, or chest, or belly, or thigh; and similar ones from those limbs. 
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am stating the cures of some wounds, so that I may put that reasoning and rule over the other wounds. 
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will begin with simple head wounds; because the recollection of complex ones will come at the beginning of the third chapter. 
Dico ergo.	Therefore, I say. 
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When a simple wound occurs on the head, and there is no bone fracture; then consider if it is from the throw of a stone, or similar things, and has already broken only the skin: and the wound is large, and you fear for an unfavorable outcome of hot abscesses; then hurry and perform cephalic phlebotomy immediately; and do not delay it; and extract blood from him according to the amount of his strength: if there is nothing prohibiting phlebotomy, especially if the blood that comes out from the wound is little. 
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be from the opposite side of the wounded part.  
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the sick person beware of overeating, and wine, and heavy foods. 
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	But if something prohibits reduction, then let him reduce from food, and not approach meats, nor wines. 
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And place upon the wound, if a hot abscess happens to him, cotton infused in rose oil alone, or with wine in which there is astringency.  
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	But if you are safe from a hot abscess, then place upon the wound, if it is fresh with its own blood and the air has not yet changed it, powder which I will state later a little: and if the air has already changed it, then place some ointments upon it until it heals. 
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	But if the wound is large, or is from a cut by a sword, and similar instruments, and its edges do not come together by themselves, then bring them together with suture, as I shall explain concerning wounds of the belly. 
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	But if the wound is already separated from the bone, and hangs down, and there is no retention of it except by a small suspensory bandage: then cut it. 
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then treat the wound with medicines and restore hard flesh in place of the skin, and instruct the patient to eat foods which are nourishing, such as meat and cooked wheat, until he is fat; and those similar. 
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	But if you find putrefaction in the skin and it does not adhere to the bone: then cut out all the putrefaction and discard it; then treat that area.  
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	But if in these wounds there is an artery or vein from which blood flows and it is not stopped by medicines, then examine the artery above. 
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If therefore you find it uncut, then cut it with a scalpel or tie it off.  
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if necessity compels when that which we have said does not work, then burn it until the blood is stopped. 
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	But if these wounds are small and simple, then their treatment is easy and light so that you sprinkle this powder over them: because it hardens them before the air changes them. 
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method of Making Flesh-Colored Powder
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part frankincense and two parts dragon's blood and three parts unquenched lime; grind the whole thoroughly and sift it. Fill the wound with this powder and constrict it well with a bandage until it adheres firmly to it and coagulates with the blood.  
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then bind it over with bandages and leave it alone; do not unbind it until it remains so that it does not fester.  
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For it is not eradicated by medicine until it is healed. 
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And sometimes lime alone does this when you do not have frankincense at hand, and dragon's blood also performs the same operation in many large wounds when it is fitting to place it upon them and bind, and they are recent wounds with their own blood which has not been altered by air. 
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	But if it has already been altered by air, especially when it is in the summertime, then this powder is not intended for use; therefore treat it with what we said so that you place certain digestive ointments upon them; or place poultices of barley flour made with water and honey upon them until they discharge pus. 
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with the remaining care until they are healed. 
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	But if it should happen that there is a fracture in the bone with the wound, and it is small, then extract it with forceps; and I will now speak of the treatment of skull fractures in what is to come. 
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Concerning wounds of the neck. 
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter Eighty-Five. 
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	But if a wound should happen in the neck, then there is no difference in its treatment and that of a head wound when it is simple. 
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	But if a nerve or artery of the neck has already been cut, then if it is a nerve, there is no remedy except to apply treatment that produces strong astringency, such as alum, and za'faran, and those similar to them. 
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	Because they are harmful to nerves and contract them. 
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not place anything cold at all upon the wound; because the substance of nerves is cold, and its continuation is with the brain, which is the most exalted of the members; and let that with which it is treated be from mild medicines, such as lime slaked with fresh water repeatedly infused with oil, or with rose oil, and tutty when it is washed even with fresh water: and the remaining mineral stones, in this manner, and humid ointments. 
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	But if the wound is large, then apply a suture; or bring together its lips with poultices. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals. 
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	But if the wound has depth, or a sinus occurs in its lower part, in which pus has already collected, then perforate it in a more depressed place within it. 
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	And if an artery has already been cut in the wound and its flow of blood has followed; then separate or dry it and bind it; or cauterize it if necessity compels it. 
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	But if the spine of the throat has already fallen, or all of it, and its ligaments are saved; then join the lips of the skin with a suture over the trachea, and do not touch the throat, rather equalize it, and reduce it to its natural form. 
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then bind it with a decent constriction, and let it go for several days. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments in which there is astringency and desiccation until it heals. 
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	But if the wound has already made an impression on the bone, then explore it; then if there are bone fragments in it, extract all of them, or as many as you can from them; and what is not prepared, leave it until the wound putrifies, and separates and its egress alleviates.  
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	But if the wound is recent, then sprinkle powder which I have described upon it. 
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	But if bone appears to be seen in the wound, and a fistula is formed; then care for it with that of which mention comes in its chapter.  
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	Concerning a Wound on the Shoulder Blades
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter Eighty-Six. 
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is a thrust by a spear or knife; and you see its depth, then consider. 
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	Therefore if windiness comes forth from the wound when a weak person breathes from it, then you will know that the wound is mortal.  
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If it is not deep and fresh with its own blood: then do not put powder on it in the first hour, nor bind it up, so that the blood may not be retained in its depth and return to the heart and kill the sick person: but put an attractive ointment on it and dissolve it twice a day. 
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	But if you do not have ointment present, then put an old rag in the wound opening so that it may draw out what flows from it of moistures; and make the sick person sleep upon the wound so that what collects in it may run. 
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	But if three or more days have already passed since the wound and no spasm occurs to the sick person, nor evil trembling of the heart, nor constriction in breathing, and you see that his other dispositions are good: then know that the wound is healed.  
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Therefore care for it with washes and the rest of its treatment until it heals. 
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	But if its healing is excused and it is always opened up, then know that a fistula has already been made. 
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Therefore care for it from its own chapter.  
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if a wound is from the incision of a sword or knife and it is simple on the surface of the chest or back, then care for it with what preceded from suture if it is large; or with powder if it is small. 
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if it has already made an impression on the bone and chips come from it, then probe the wound and hurry to extract those chips if they are separate. 
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	But if they are not separate, then leave them until the wound rots; for their extraction is relieved then.  
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	But judgment in the treatment of other accidental wounds in other limbs is the judgment that we said.  
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Of wounds of the belly and the exits of intestines and their outlets. 
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter 87
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	Disruption which happens to the abdomen is great, and medium, and small. 
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	From a great one therefore sometimes an intestine, or a number of intestines, comes out.  
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Therefore the introduction of them is made, and their suture more vehement and difficult. 
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And a small disruption also becomes difficult in another way.  
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	It follows therefore that the reduction of them is more difficult if you do not hurry in their introduction to their place immediately: because it is inflated, opened, and enlarged: therefore its entry becomes difficult. 
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Because of this, therefore a medium disruption is better: because with it the reduction of the intestine is not difficult, as it becomes difficult in these two kinds.  
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that the suture of a vein is according to four methods. 
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two sutures are common and apply to the suture of the abdomen, and to the suture of the remaining wounds of the body: and two other sutures properly pertain to the remaining wounds. 
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However they are more proper with the suture of the abdomen: and I will tell you each one with explanation and declaration. 
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say therefore that when a wound is small, and something comes out of it from the intestine, and it is difficult to reduce it: then it is because of one of two methods.  
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the smallness of the disruption, as we said: Or because there is inflation in the intestine because of the cold of the air. 
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	Therefore when it is so, it is necessary that you warm it, so that you immerse a sponge, or cloth dampened in lukewarm water only.  
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or you boil in water squints and cypress and saffron and embrace it with the intestine until inflation is resolved.  
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	Sometimes wine in which there is astringency makes it: and it is better than water alone in the resolution of inflation. 
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When therefore you see the swelling already resolved, then moisten the intestine with water in which has been boiled marshmallow or mallow. 
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For through that its entry is eased with a small thing. 
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	But if its return is excused after this treatment, then make a small incision in the disruption with an instrument by which hemorrhoids are cut. 
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first treatment is better when prepared than a section: and there is no compulsion to cut after necessity and defect of the instrument.  
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part of it be twisted and pointed, and the other part not pointed, and let the fine end not be with the fineness of a spatula, but rather be a little blunter: and it is that which resembles a chisel, as you see. 
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When therefore the wound is enlarged and enters the intestine, then it is necessary that its reduction be according to its own natural form in its proper place if possible above it; for it is better. 
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	But when the disruption is wide in the lower part of the belly: then it is necessary that you make the sick person lie on its back, and put their legs higher than their head. 
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the belly, then put its head and chest higher than its lower parts. 
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And similarly if there is a disruption in one of the two parts of the belly, then put your attention and your consideration always on this, that the part in which the wound is be higher than the other part. 
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And thus it is necessary that you administer it in large wounds and in medium wounds.  
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But in small wounds, put it according to what is prepared for you. 
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make a pious minister be present between your hands who will hold the whole disruption with his hand: and join its lips. 
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then uncover from it for him who follows a suture something after something: and this is the manner of a common single suture. 
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And take a needle, or several needles, according to the size of the wound. 
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then let fall from the end of the disruption a quantity equal to the breadth of the ring finger, that is, a physician's breadth; and fix one needle beyond which you shall introduce a thread into both extremities of the skin, with both extremities of the sifac which is under the skin, until you make it penetrate from the other side, and you have now brought together two extremities of the skin, and two extremities of the sifac: and there are four rows. 
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then bind with a double thread around the needle several times on both sides at once, until the two lips of the wound are joined together in a decent manner.  
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then let fall a quantity equal to the breadth of a finger, and fix another needle in them; then draw it tight with thread, just as you did with the first needle.  
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Therefore do not cease to do that with as many needles as you need until you complete the constriction of the whole wound. 
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let the needles be of medium size between thinness and thickness; because very thin needles pierce the flesh quickly, and thick ones have a difficult entry into the skin; therefore it is necessary that they are of medium thinness and thickness.  
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it is not necessary that the needle be fixed in the two extremities of the skin very close together; lest the flesh be pierced quickly and the wound opened before its healing, and lest they also be lengthened with the suture, lest the wound be prevented from healing. 
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut off the ends of the needles so that they do not injure the sick man during his sleep; and put little wads of cloth on all sides to hold the ends of the needles; and leave them until you know that the wound is already healed. 
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this indeed, a species of suture with needles thus arranged, is more suitable for small wounds.  
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	Because one, or two, or about that number of needles suffice in the suturing of them.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second suture is common, so that you bring together the extremities of four with a suture: two extremities of skin and two extremities of fascia in one stitch, with a needle which has thread wound equally fine and thick. 
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have pierced these four extremities with the needle, draw back the needle from the part where you began, so that the drawn thread may fall from the upper part of the wound: let the suture be like the suture of cloth whereby cloths are tied, and put between every suture a quantity equal to the thickness of the little finger.  
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	But men know this suture. 
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this suture I healed a wound which had happened to a man in his belly, who had been wounded with a knife and the disruption of the wound was greater than a palm; and about two palms had come out from the intestines from the middle intestine, and the disruption was in the middle of the belly. 
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	I therefore returned it after his intestines had stood outside the wound for twenty-four hours.  
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	The wound therefore became consolidated in the space of about fifteen days; and I cared for it and it was healed; and he lived afterward for many years, returning to his usual ways. 
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the physicians had judged that it would not be healed. 
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And it was a marvel that I did not treat it with ointment.  
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because I was in a place where ointment was not to be found, nor anything of medicine.  
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	I therefore put old linen upon the wound twice a day and constantly washed it with honey water until it was healed. 
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	But I will tell two kinds of sutures proper according to the telling of speech.  
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is, that you begin with a sharp suture; and insert the needle from the outer to the inner part.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When therefore the needle has penetrated the skin and gone into the muscle following the length and breadth of the whole body: let the extremity of the fascia fall on the side in which you inserted the needle, and make it penetrate into the other extremity from the inner part to the outer part at the other extremity. 
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When therefore you have made it penetrate, then make it penetrate thus in the same extremity from the outer part to the inner: and let go the sifac extremity which is on this side, and make the needle penetrate into the other extremity from the inner part to the outer; and make it penetrate with the penetration that you make it penetrate into the sifac extremity which is in its part until it penetrates into the whole. 
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then begin also from the same side and with its extremity which is from the sifac on the other side, and draw out the needle from the skin that it penetrated. 
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then return it into that skin and its sifac extremity which is on the other side with this mirach extremity; and draw it out from the skin which is from its part, and do this alternately one by one, and another; and do this alternately after another until you have extracted all of its extrinsic parts according to that example. 
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the sum of this suture is that its sutures be like those of skin layers; so that its sifac be alternately on one side with one extremity of skin; and that you let it go alternately on the other side, until you complete it. 
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of suture proper which Gale said. 
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This speech of his is narrated so that its suture be according to the likeness which some physicians make, so that they bring together every part to its corresponding fellow according to nature; and apply the sifac extremity to its other extremity, and the mirach extremity to its other extremity. 
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this is done according to what I tell you. 
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	It is necessary that you fix the needle in the mirach extremity nearest to you from the outer part and make it penetrate to the inner in that alone; and let go the two sifac extremities. 
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then turn the needle and make it penetrate from the outer part to the inner in the two sifac extremities, namely on both sides.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then turn both [instruments] over and make them penetrate from the inside to the outside, at two extremities of a pair of other forceps, which are on the opposite side. 
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of suture is better than the common easy suture, and it is a suture of which remembrance preceded. 
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is therefore also the speech of Galen. 
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some have said. 
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The suture of the belly is corrected with two needles.  
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	Which is, to insert one thread into both of them; and begin with the insertion of the needle, from that which is at your side, and make it penetrate up to the other side, according to the suture of those who are leather equally.  
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And know that when the disruption is in the middle of the belly, then its suture is more difficult than that of the remaining parts of the belly. 
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgment indeed of the medication of a wound, is the judgment of other wounds.  
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	Which is, because when you attain a fresh wound with its own blood, before the air alters it; and you reduce the intestine, and its own, and fit it; then place powder of incarnating on top. 
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	But if the air has already altered the wound, then place on it certain ointments which are present to you, until they make pus; and the threads fall away, and the sutures consolidate, and heal. 
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it as is the care of other wounds, until it is healed. 
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if medicines are not present to you, then place on it immediately, from when it begins to emit pus, old lint; and change it twice a day, as I have taught you, until it is healed.  
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not need another medication in many dispositions, when wounds are simple. 
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	But if you fear that the wound may communicate to the principal members in injury, then it is necessary that you immerse soft wool in oil of tempered warmth, or in rose oil; and place it around the parts which are between the groins, and under the armpits. 
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If he feels pain, or pricks, or putrefaction in his bowels (for this often happens) then give him an enema with strong black wine, warm: especially if the putrefaction has already reached the intestine and is about to penetrate as far as its cavity. 
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that what is from the large intestine is of easier healing: and what is from them out of the subtle, more difficult to heal. 
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	But the intestine which is called Jejunum does not admit healing from a wound that happens in it at all: and this is because of its multitude, which is from veins, and their size, and because of the subtlety of its body, and the nearness of its nature to nerves.  
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	But if that which proceeds from the wound is a protuberance, and you overtake it fresh: reduce it according to your reduction, by which you reduce intestines equally. 
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if a space has passed it, and it has already become green or black: then it is necessary that you constrict it with thread above the place which has been blackened from it, so that a flow of blood does not happen. 
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in a protuberance are veins and arteries.  
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut what is beyond that ligament, and place two ends of the thread hanging from the lower part of the wound outside it: so that relief comes upon you from its attraction, and extraction of it in case of a protuberance, and emission of pus from the wound. 
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	A Reminder of a Wound That Happens in the Intestine. 
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When a rupture happens in the intestine, and it is small: then it is possible that it may be restored in some men: therefore because I have seen one who was wounded in his belly with a thrust of a lance, and the wound was from the right side of the stomach, and the wound became old: and a fistula was made, and there issued forth from it discharge, and flatulence. 
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	Therefore I applied treatment until I was no longer anxious about its healing; nor did I cease to refine it, until it was healed and the site consolidated. 
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw the site already consolidated, I feared for the patient, that some bad accident might befall him in his abdomen; and no such bad accident befell him from then on. 
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in better dispositions, eating and drinking, and defecating, and entering the bath, and exercising himself in his diet. 
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And already some experimenters have said that when a wound occurs in the intestine and is small, then it ought to be tied according to this method. 
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is, that you take ants of large heads.  
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound, and place one ant from those which have an open mouth upon the two lips of the wound.  
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When therefore its head is on them and it bites down with its mouth, cut off its head, for it will adhere and not be released.  
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first one, and do not cease doing this with an ant after an ant according to the total quantity of the wound. 
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce it, and its wound.  
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For those heads will remain attached in the intestine until the intestine is nourished and healed, and no harm befall the patient deeply. 
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And already it is possible that the intestine may be tied even with a fine thread; which has been drawn out from the intestine of an animal, attached to it after it is inserted into a needle. 
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And it is, that you take the end of this thread from the intestine, and it should be scraped off very much.  
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then tie at its end a fine thread of flax wrapped around it. 
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert that thread into a needle and with it the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then put it back into its separation. 
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of suture with ants and intestines is not except according to the way of trust and hope. 
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know that a wound which is large, wide, especially if it is in one of the slender intestines: then there is no remedy except refinement, and its healing is not at all. 
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	On the Care of Fistulas and Zuchemen. 
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter Eighty-Eight.
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Know that every wound or abscess when it grows old and becomes ancient, and becomes an ulcer and does not consolidate, and always discharges pus and is not cut off: then it is universally called a fistula, wherever it may be in the limb; and we call it Zuchemen. 
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula indeed is according to truth a filtered knot, hard, white: with which there is no pain and which has the concavity of a bird's feather: and because of that some call it Risati, that is, a feather. 
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And it is sometimes moist in certain hours, which discharges pus. 
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps the moisture splits in certain hours.  
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes this moisture is much, and sometimes little: and it is thick, and sometimes thin. 
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I already stated previously in the division when I said wounds that every sore which does not heal and flesh is not born in it, it is not except because of one of nine new causes. 
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	Of which one is, either because of the lack of blood in the body; or because of its malice; or because there is tough flesh between it and its upper lips, preventing the birth of flesh; or because there is much filth and squalor; or because the sore itself is putrid, and the material sent to it is of bad quality; or because the medicine is inconvenient in its healing; or because corruption falling in the region is a kind of pestilence; or through a property in the region, as happens in Caesaraugusta: in which digestion of illnesses is difficult and healing of abscesses by nature is delayed; or because there is one bone, or a number of bones in it. 
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have now shown all these causes and their signs, and their treatments with medicines in division; and it is necessary here that I make you know the treatment of Fistula and Zuken, which is done by the way of operation with the hand. 
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	Therefore, know that Fistula occurs in all members of the body. 
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For from them are Fistulas which reach the large veins and arteries, or nerves, or sinews: or to the intestine, or to the bladder, or to one of the ribs: or to one of the vertebrae of the back, or to one of the joints composed in composition: such as the hand, and foot; and from them are those which go to the proximity of the principal member, and similar ones.  
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Which therefore of these Fistulas is according to this manner, is from illnesses difficult of healing, and does not receive healing, and occupation with it is toil and ignorance.  
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	But if it is from Fistulas some of whose depth does not reach these places which I said: and you hope, and trust in its healing, and wish to arrive at the knowledge of it, then take a probe of bronze, or iron, if the Fistula extends according to straightness, and explore it with it. 
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	But if there is crookedness in the Fistula, then investigate it with a probe of fine lead.  
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	For lead, with the gentleness of its body, is relieved, and curves around the crookedness. 
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	But if the Fistula has many openings, it is not possible for you to indicate upon it with a probe.  
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore wash out one of the openings from its openings. 
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the moisture with which you wash it, goes towards the other openings, and runs out from them.  
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then carefully inquire according to which manner it is possible for you: that you may know whether there is a bone, or nerve, and the Fistula's cavity is distant, or near: or whether the Fistula is one which has many openings, and stand over all of it, with your greatest strength: with questioning of yours, with which you question the sick person, and finding pain at compression with your hand upon the place, and similar things from signs and causes arising as an abscess. 
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when you have stood upon all that true station, then go to the cure according to confidence: and it is, that you consider then, if there is a Fistula nearby apparent, or in a safe place far from the joint, or from a nerve, or artery, or vein, or one of the places which I told you: then cut the Fistula according to what was stated from my narration, and remove what is in it from filtration, and corrupted flesh, which arises in its orifice from flesh, or thelul, and similar things: and cure it, until it is healed. 
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	But if the Fistula is of distant depth, and is according to straightness: then it is necessary that you cut it deeply as much as is possible for you. 
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then clean it from all its corrupted flesh. 
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then apply linen wrapped in sharp medicines: and insert it up to the cavity of the Fistula which you comprehended with iron: do this several times with it until the sharp medicine eats away all that remains in the cavity of the Fistula from corruption. 
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with ointments which generate healthy flesh, until it is healed. 
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	But if it does not heal through that, then cauterize it according to what we narrated. 
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	But if the cause of the Fistula is a bone, and it is certified to you: then inquire about it, and cut it according to what I narrated to you: if nothing prevents you from a vein, or nerve, or principal member, as we said. 
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If therefore the bone is revealed to you, and there is something of corruption and blackness in it: then scrape it, until all its corruption is removed. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then cure it with what makes it flesh again, until it is healed.  
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	But if it does not heal and emits pus as it was doing: then know that you have not reached the total eradication of corruption. 
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore uncover it a second time and make a careful incision into it, and cleanse it with your greatest care. 
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it. 
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If then it heals, it is good; and if not, then know that the corruption is deep within the body, which you have not reached. 
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	Therefore there is no skill for you in it except to leave it to nature.  
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	But if the mouth of a young child is corrupted, and it is possible for you, draw it out with fine forceps that are suitable for it. 
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	But if there are many bones, then carefully draw them all out, and do not leave any of them with your strength. 
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	But if something opposes you from the humors and there is no fear or mistake in their incision; then cut into those humors and flesh, if they are there, and free the bones. 
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	But if you are not prepared to remove the bones in your time, then place over the wound something that will cause it to rot; and leave it until what is around those bones rots from flesh and humors. 
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And watch the wound so that it does not solidify. 
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And constrict the section which you cut in your operation.  
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	Rather place over it, if you fear, a cloth immersed in sulfur ground with oil; or a cloth immersed in Egyptian ointment, or some green ointments. 
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those humors rot and separate from the bones, their removal is eased and their attraction. 
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	But if there is one large bone, such as the bone of the leg or hip bone, and similar to them, and what is corrupted from it is a large part; then scrape it with the last incision until that blackness and corruption is removed. 
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the wound. 
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	But if what is corrupted in it is a large part and the corruption has already reached the marrow of the bone, then you must saw it and cut it entirely up to the place where the corruption reaches; then care for it until it heals together. 
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you a story that happened to a man in his leg, so that you may take it as an example and help for your operation. 
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	There was a young man about thirty years old, to whom came pain in his leg, from a cause which moved within him, that is, from his insides, until the materials reached his leg, and there formed a large abscess: and he had no external cause. 
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	Time was extended with him in error of the physicians until the abscess was opened and many materials flowed forth with it. 
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And his treatment was postponed until his leg became fistulous and many openings were made in it, which all emitted pus and the humors of the body.
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	A multitude of physicians treated him for about two years, and there was no one wise in the art of the hand among them, until I was called and I saw his leg and the materials which flowed from those openings with great force: even his whole body had already wasted away, and his color was citron. 
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	Therefore I inserted a probe into one of the openings and it reached the bone.
